context: Scientists are discussing ways to remove excess carbon dioxide from the atmosphere by increasing the amount that is absorbed by plant life. One plan to accomplish this is to establish giant floating seaweed farms in the oceans. When the seaweed plants die, they will be disposed of by being burned for fuel.
question: Explain why the fact that some people may be reluctant to switch to the new fuel even if seaweed farms prove effective does not indicate a serious weakness in the plan.
answer0: The seaweed farms do not necessarily have to be located in the Southern Hemisphere.
answer1: People's willingness to use seaweed as a fuel source is not directly related to its effectiveness in removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, since the seaweed plants can be burned as fuel without people actually using the fuel's energy.
answer2: While these figures may be accurate, they are subject to change, and more plants like seaweed can be grown to increase the amount of carbon dioxide absorbed by plants.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Many scientific studies have suggested that taking melatonin tablets can induce sleep. But this does not mean that melatonin is helpful in treating insomnia. Most of the studies examined only people without insomnia, and in many of the studies, only a few of the subjects given melatonin appeared to be significantly affected by it.
question: Explain why the fact that none of the studies that suggested that taking melatonin tablets can induce sleep examined a fully representative sample of the human population does not strengthen the argument.
answer0: The text implies that melatonin is not helpful to people with insomnia. If all people who took melatonin were effected then that would weaken the argument presented in the text.
answer1: This would not strengthen the argument in the text since people given the placebo were able to sleep. This would imply that is was not the melatonin inducing sleep but something else.
answer2: This would not strengthen the argument in the text. Since a good sample was not taken, you can not generalize the results to the population.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease: white blood cells attack the myelin sheath that protects nerve fibers in the spinal cord and brain. Medical science now has a drug that can be used to successfully treat multiple sclerosis, but the path that led medical researchers to this drug was hardly straightforward. Initially, some scientists believed attacks characteristic of multiple sclerosis might be triggered by chronic viral infections. So in 1984 they began testing gamma interferon, one of the body' s own antiviral weapons. To their horror, all the multiple sclerosis patients tested became dramatically worse. The false step proved to be instructive however.
question: Explain why the fact that gamma interferon stops white blood cells from producing myelin-destroying compounds is not compatible with the results of the gamma interferon experiment.
answer0: If gamma interferon stops white blood cells from producing myelin-destroying compounds, the multiple sclerosis patients that were tested with gamma interferon should have improved rather than becoming worse.
answer1: If gamma interferon spikes before and during multiple sclerosis attacks, then it is likely that a treatment which increases gamma interferon would be associated with a worsening of multiple sclerosis symptoms.
answer2: If gamma interferon causes a worsening of symptoms in those with multiple sclerosis, then a drug that inhibits the activity of gamma interferon should help to improve symptoms of multiple sclerosis.
answer3: If gamma interferon causes an increase in the number of white blood cells in those without multiple sclerosis, it may do the same in those with multiple sclerosis, and that increase in white blood cells would cause an increase in attacks on the myelin sheath of the nerve fibers for those with multiple sclerosis.

main_question.context: Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease: white blood cells attack the myelin sheath that protects nerve fibers in the spinal cord and brain. Medical science now has a drug that can be used to successfully treat multiple sclerosis, but the path that led medical researchers to this drug was hardly straightforward. Initially, some scientists believed attacks characteristic of multiple sclerosis might be triggered by chronic viral infections. So in 1984 they began testing gamma interferon, one of the body' s own antiviral weapons. To their horror, all the multiple sclerosis patients tested became dramatically worse. The false step proved to be instructive however.
main_question.question: Which one of the following is LEAST compatible with the results of the gamma interferon experiment?
main_question.option: Gamma interferon stops white blood cells from producing myelin-destroying compounds.

question: Why is it compatible to conclude that administering gamma interferon to those without multiple sclerosis causes an increase in the number of white blood cells based on the results of the gamma interferon experiment?
answer0: If gamma interferon causes a worsening of symptoms in those with multiple sclerosis, then a drug that inhibits the activity of gamma interferon should help to improve symptoms of multiple sclerosis.
answer1: If gamma interferon causes an increase in the number of white blood cells in those without multiple sclerosis, it may do the same in those with multiple sclerosis, and that increase in white blood cells would cause an increase in attacks on the myelin sheath of the nerve fibers for those with multiple sclerosis.
answer2: If gamma interferon spikes before and during multiple sclerosis attacks, then it is likely that a treatment which increases gamma interferon would be associated with a worsening of multiple sclerosis symptoms.
answer3: If gamma interferon stops white blood cells from producing myelin-destroying compounds, the multiple sclerosis patients that were tested with gamma interferon should have improved rather than becoming worse.

context: The population of songbirds throughout England has decreased in recent years. Many people explain this decrease as the result of an increase during the same period in the population of magpies, which eat the eggs and chicks of songbirds.
question: Why does the fact that the number of eggs laid yearly by a female songbird varies widely according to the songbird's species not argue strongly against the explanation reported in the passage?
answer0: If areas with decreased songbird populations are not among those where magpies increased, it suggests that the larger data set is misleading and contains irrelevant information.
answer1: The number of eggs typically laid by different species of songbirds has no bearing on what a magpie's effect would be on their overall population.
answer2: This only adds an explanation for why the population of magpies increased, which is unneeded and provides nothing in determining an explanation that applies to songbird populations.
answer3: The fact that magpies' diets include foods other than eggs and chicks of songbirds tells nothing about their influence on songbird populations.

context: Ph. D. programs are valuable only if they inculcate good scholarship and expedite the student' s full participation in the field. Hence, doctoral dissertations should not be required in the humanities. Undertaking a quality book-length dissertation demands an accumulation of knowledge virtually impossible for those relatively new to their disciplines. The student consequently either seeks to compensate for poor quality with quantity or ends up spending years producing a work of quality. Either way, the dissertation is counterproductive and frustrates the appropriate goals of the doctoral program.
question: Why does the claim that doctoral dissertations should not be required in the humanities not provide evidence for the assumption that requirements for degrees in the humanities differ from requirements for degrees in other disciplines?
answer0: The article is attempting to persuade readers that the dissertation process is harmful to the humanities.
answer1: The article is not a descriptive one attempting to record observations of the dissertation process, but rather arguing to abolish it.
answer2: The article is not attempting to compare and contrast degree requirements across fields, but rather argues that the humanities will benefit from eliminating the dissertation requirement.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Eighteenth-century European aesthetics was reasonably successful in providing an understanding of all art, including early abstract art, until the 1960s, when artists self-consciously rebelled against earlier notions of art. Since the work of these rebellious artists is quite beautiful but outside the bounds of the aesthetic theory then current, there can be no complete theory of aesthetics.
question: Why is the reasoning not considered to be flawed for assuming that it is more important for a complete aesthetic theory to account for the beauty of traditional art than for it to account for the beauty of self-consciously rebellious art?
answer0: The passage is assuming that European aesthetics is encompassing, this option raises the flaw in that.
answer1: The passage has nothing to do with other parts of the world, only European aesthetics.
answer2: The passage states that they were rebelling against earlier notions of art. This option goes against that by saying they were not guided, in some way, by it.
answer3: This does not apply. The passage has nothing to do with it being more important.

context: Scientist: My research indicates that children who engage in impulsive behavior similar to adult thrill-seeking behavior are twice as likely as other children to have a gene variant that increases sensitivity to dopamine. From this, I conclude that there is a causal relationship between this gene variant and an inclination toward thrill-seeking behavior.
question: Why does the fact that children are often described by adults as engaging in thrill-seeking behavior simply because they act impulsively not call into question the scientist's argument?
answer0: Thrill seeking behavior is associated with a gene that would not change from childhood to adulthood.
answer1: Whether or not adults are sensitive to dopamine as it is children's sensitivity to dopamine that is referenced in connection with their behavior.
answer2: Impulsive behavior is defined differently depending on a wide variety of circumstances and situations.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Columnist: Over the last 20 years the demand in North America for Japanese-made automobiles has increased, whereas the Japanese demand for North American-made automobiles has been stagnant. Until recently, this imbalance could plausibly be attributed to Japanese models' superior fuel efficiency and reliability, but now cars made in North America are by these standards the equal of any Japanese model. What North American exporters continue to ignore is that the Japanese drive on the left side of the road. Ttherefore, one obstacle to reducing the automotive trade imbalance will be removed if North American manufacturers simply produce more cars with right-side steering wheels.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the columnist's argument requires the assumption that if the Japanese drive on the left side of the road, then they are not inclined to buy cars with left-side steering wheels?
answer0: Sales of American cars to Japan have not increased even as fuel efficiency and reliability have become more similar among different manufacturers, so there is no evidence that most Japanese would choose the North American model among all cars with right-side steering wheels.
answer1: The columnist's argument is that American auto sales to Japan would be increased by manufacturing more cars with right-side steering wheels, so it is necessary to assume that the Japanese would not want to buy cars with left-side steering wheels.
answer2: There may be ways to correct the automotive trade imbalance other than specifically meeting the needs Japanese buyers.
answer3: None of the above choices

question: What is the reasoning that suggests that the columnist's argument does not require the assumption that given a choice between similar Japanese and North American models, all with right-side steering wheels, most Japanese would choose the North American model?
answer0: The columnist's argument is that American auto sales to Japan would be increased by manufacturing more cars with right-side steering wheels, so it is necessary to assume that the Japanese would not want to buy cars with left-side steering wheels.
answer1: Sales of American cars to Japan have not increased even as fuel efficiency and reliability have become more similar among different manufacturers, so there is no evidence that most Japanese would choose the North American model among all cars with right-side steering wheels.
answer2: There may be ways to correct the automotive trade imbalance other than specifically meeting the needs Japanese buyers.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: The United States government generally tries to protect valuable natural resources. But one resource has been ignored for too long. In the United States, each bushel of corn produced might result in the loss of as much as two bushels of topsoil. Moreover, in the last 100 years, the topsoil in many states, which once was about fourteen inches thick, has been eroded to only six or eight inches. Nonetheless, federal expenditures for nationwide soil conservation programs have remained at ridiculously low levels. Total federal expenditures for nationwide soil conservation programs have been less than the allocations of some individual states.
question: Why does the fact that the federal government's expenditures for soil conservation in the various states have been inequitable not express the main point of the argument?
answer0: There was o comparison in the cost effectiveness of corn. There was only a comparison of amount of topsoil used per bushel of corn.
answer1: Stating that the total federal spending is below what some individual states spends serves to highlight how little they have spent. The text states that soil conservation has been ignored. This implies that the government needs to spend more to converse the soil.
answer2: Soil conservation from both the state and federal government was mentioned in the text, with no preference for who is responsible.
answer3: The text does not mention how much money is spend in each state by the government. It only mentions the total spending to be less that what some of the states spend themselves.

context: Ten years ago, the Salisbury City Council passed the Culinary Bill, new legislation to protect the interests of local non-franchise restaurants. Of the 120 local non-franchise restaurants in Salisbury today, 85 opened during the last ten years. Clearly the Culinary Bill has caused a surge in the number of local non-franchise restaurants operating in Salisbury over the past ten years.
question: What is the reasoning for why the argument does not depend on the assumption that all economic indicators suggest that household incomes in Salisbury have risen substantially over the past ten years?
answer0: The passage makes no mention of household incomes in Salisbury and only focuses upon the Culinary Bill and the amount of restaurants that remain open today.
answer1: The passage tells us that there are 120 non-franchise restaurants in Salisbury and that of those 120 restaurants 85 opened in the last ten years.
answer2: The bills is stated to have been created to protect the interests of non-franchise restaurants as well as being stated to have caused a surge in the number of non-franchise restaurants in the city.
answer3: We have no knowledge from the passage as to whether or not patrons are aware of the Bill and its intentions or not. Assuming the patrons are or are not informed would be erroneous.

context: Microbiologist: A lethal strain of salmonella recently showed up in a European country, causing an outbreak of illness that killed two people and infected twenty-seven others. Investigators blame the severity of the outbreak on the overuse of antibiotics, since the salmonella bacteria tested were shown to be drug-resistant. But this is unlikely because patients in the country where the outbreak occurred cannot obtain antibiotics to treat illness without a prescription, and the country's doctors prescribe antibiotics less readily than do doctors in any other European country.
question: Explain why the fact that Salmonella has been shown to spread easily along the distribution chains of certain vegetables, such as raw tomatoes, does not weaken the microbiologist's reasoning.
answer0: The text did not mention how the bacteria was spread. How the bacteria spreads will not effect if the bacteria is antibiotic resistance.
answer1: The text does not mention how much antibiotic use has increased or decreased in any country. And even if the use had increased in neighboring countries, it has no effect on the amount of antibiotics prescribed in the country with the outbreak and no bearing on whether the bacteria in the country with the outbreak are antibiotic resistant.
answer2: The text states that these doctors prescribe less antibiotics than other countries, but does not give a reason for this. But whatever the reason for not prescribing the antibiotics would still mean the bacteria would not be antibiotic resistant.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: The striking similarities between Greek temples and subsequent Roman villas testify to the fact that great architects typically draw inspiration from the work of other architects. Such drawing of inspiration does not mean, however, a slavish lack of originality; building according to formulas does not make good buildings. When formulas are used, the results are either bland or disastrous. By contrast, a great architect creates fresh architectural compositions out of familiar forms and synthesizes past and present into a new, richer whole.
question: Explain why it is not valid to infer from the passage that some Greek temples were not themselves inspired by older models.
answer0: The opposite is true, in fact it is basic or formulaic design that leads to bland or disastrous architecture.
answer1: It is stated the Greek temples did in fact draw inspiration from the past works of other architects.
answer2: Good Roman architects put a fresh spin on past architectural ideas, so they were not lacking in originality or thought.
answer3: None of the above choices

Such drawing of inspiration does not mean, however, a slavish lack of originality; building according to formulas does not make good buildings. When formulas are used, the results are either bland or disastrous. By contrast, a great architect creates fresh architectural compositions out of familiar forms and synthesizes past and present into a new, richer whole.
main_question.question: Which one of the following can be inferred from the passage?
main_question.option: Buildings with unfamiliar forms are likely to be either bland or architectural disasters.

context: Pundit: Grenier will almost certainly not be elected as mayor. Although she says she believes in raising city employees' wages, it was only a few years ago that she was arguing that their wages should not be increased. Her claim that she has learned more about the issue since then -- though sincere -- will not matter to most voters, who will see her as insincere.
question: Explain why the principle that voters are unlikely to be influenced by what a politician's views were in the past if the voters agree with the politician's current positions does not help to justify the pundit's reasoning.
answer0: Voters questioning a politician's sincerity does not mean that the voters are unwilling or unlikely to vote for the politician.
answer1: It is unclear how many voters would or would not vote for Grenier based on her current view of wanting to raising city employees' wages, so it cannot be concluded that her current position would cause her to lose the election for mayor.
answer2: The pundit thinks that Grenier's change in stance on city employees' wages will be viewed by voters as insincere, so they would therefore be unlikely to vote for Grenier, supporting the pundit's conclusion that Grenier will most likely not be elected mayor.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: The solidity of bridge piers built on pilings depends largely on how deep the pilings are driven. Prior to 1700, pilings were driven to "refusal, " that is, to the point at which they refused to go any deeper. In a 1588 inquiry into the solidity of piers for Venice' s Rialto Bridge, it was determined that the bridge' s builder, Antonio Da Ponte, had met the contemporary standard for refusal: he had caused the pilings to be driven until additional penetration into the ground was no greater than two inches after twenty-four hammer blows.
question: Explain why it is not valid to infer from the passage that Da Ponte's standard of refusal was less strict than that of other bridge builders of his day.
answer0: There is no indication that the pilings were unsafe.
answer1: The mention of the standard being the "contemporary" standard implies that the standard may be different now and the explanation of how "refusal" is determined also leaves room for the explanation that the pilings could have been driven deeper.
answer2: There is no mention of any other standard during Da Ponte's day.
answer3: There is no mention of the standard for driving pilings after 1588.

context: To perform an act that is morally wrong is to offend against humanity, and all offenses against humanity are equally bad. Because murder is morally wrong, it is just as bad to have murdered one person by setting off a bomb as it would have been to have murdered a hundred people by setting off that bond.
question: What is the basis for concluding that, if lying is morally wrong, telling a lie is as bad as murdering someone in accordance with the principles invoked above?
answer0: If all offenses against humanity are equally bad, it only means that they are morally equal and does not mean the harm to society will be equal in every case.
answer1: If all offenses against humanity are equally bad, and both lying and murder are offenses against humanity, then both lying and murder are equally bad.
answer2: If all offenses against humanity are equally bad, it does not mean that all good actions toward humanity are equally good.
answer3: Murder is an intentional act but an accident is not, so it does not necessarily mean that an accident would be an offense against humanity or morally wrong.

context: After 1950, in response to record growth in worldwide food demand, farmers worldwide sharply increased fertilizer use. As a result, the productivity of farmland more than doubled by 1985. Since 1985, farmers have sought to increase farmland productivity even further. Nevertheless, worldwide fertilizer use has declined by 6 percent between 1985 and the present.
question: How does the fact that several varieties of crop plants that have become popular recently, such as soybeans, are as responsive to fertilizer as are traditional grain crops not help to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the information above?
answer0: If recently popular crops responded similarly to fertilizer as traditional crops, farmers would not decrease fertilizer use.
answer1: While farmers likely did increase crop yields prior to 1985, they would not reduce fertilizer use since they wished to continue increasing yields.
answer2: Trade disputes occurring between 1975 and 1980 would likely not still affect the availability of fertilizer in the present.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: In the past, combining children of different ages in one classroom was usually a failure; it resulted in confused younger children, who were given inadequate attention and instruction, and bored older ones, who had to sit through previously learned lessons. Recently, however, the practice has been revived with excellent results. Mixed-age classrooms today are stimulating to older children and enable younger children to learn much more efficiently than in standard classrooms.
question: How does the fact that today's mixed-age classrooms, unlike those of the past, emphasize group projects that are engaging to students of different ages help to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the passage?
answer0: This is the most plausible explanation because it directly addresses the main problems in mixed-aged classrooms in the past.
answer1: Class size does not address the instruction content problem that plagued mixed-aged classrooms in the past.
answer2: Classroom equipment was not noted as a cause for the poor performance of past mixed-age classrooms.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: A recent study showed that people who address problems quickly and directly are significantly less likely to have gum disease than are people who react to problems by refusing to think about them. Since stress can have a negative effect on the immune system, the study' s results clearly indicate that some forms of gum disease are caused or aggravated by suppression of the immune system.
question: What evidence is needed to support the claim that the argument does not depend on the assumption that painful conditions will interfere with a person's ability to address problems quickly and directly?
answer0: Seeking dental care as a first option cannot be assumed as there are other avenues for addressing dental problems quickly.
answer1: The author mentions stress leading to worse dental outcomes but does not say or reference how people with stressful lives react to problems.
answer2: Some forms of dental disease are caused by lowered immune system and one factor that causes this is stress.
answer3: Pain is not an indicator that problems will or will not be tackled quickly or directly.

context: Chronic fatigue syndrome is characterized by prolonged fatigue, muscular pain, and neurological problems. It is not known whether these symptoms are all caused by a single virus or whether each symptom is the result of a separate viral infection. A newly synthesized drug has been tested on those who suffer from chronic fatigue syndrome. Although the specific antiviral effects of this drug are unknown, it has lessened the severity of all of the symptoms of chronic fatigue syndrome. Thus there is evidence that chronic fatigue syndrome is, in fact, caused by one virus.
question: Why does the argument not assume that an antiviral medication that eliminates the most severe symptoms of chronic fatigue syndrome thereby cures chronic fatigue syndrome?
answer0: Whether or not all those who suffer from prolonged fatigue also suffer from neurological problems is not important to the argument of how the drug works to treat it.
answer1: The author concludes that the syndrome is caused by one virus therefore they must believe that the drug targets that one specific virus.
answer2: The severe symptoms could be relieved without the syndrome being cured entirely.
answer3: None of the above choices

It is not known whether these symptoms are all caused by a single virus or whether each symptom is the result of a separate viral infection. A newly synthesized drug has been tested on those who suffer from chronic fatigue syndrome. Although the specific antiviral effects of this drug are unknown, it has lessened the severity of all of the symptoms of chronic fatigue syndrome. Thus there is evidence that chronic fatigue syndrome is, in fact, caused by one virus.
main_question.question: The argument assumes which one of the following?
main_question.option: All those who suffer from prolonged fatigue also suffer from neurological problems.

context: One of the most important events for modern astronomy was the series of collisions, during a single week in 1994, of more than a dozen large objects with Jupiter. The collision of these objects, which once formed most of the comet Shoemaker-Levy 9, resulted in formations that showed no signs of water. There was thus no water involved in the collisions, so we know that none of the comet' s fragments penetrated to Jupiter' s lower atmosphere and that the comet was composed of rock rather than ice.
question: Why does the argument not depend on the assumption that the post-collision analysis of Jupiter showed that the formations all had exactly the same composition?
answer0: This is exactly what the passage is alluding to when it mentions that the comet would need to go lower in the atmosphere to see water.
answer1: The passage says the opposite to this that this comet had no water in it.
answer2: The passage is not saying this, it is saying that if the comet fragment went deeper into jupiters atmosphere that maybe there would be signs of water.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Stylistic evidence and laboratory evidence strongly support the claim that the magnificent painting Garden of Eden is a work of the Flemish master van Eyck. Nevertheless, the painting must have been the work of someone else, as any one with a little historical and zoological knowledge can tell merely by looking at the painting. The animals in the painting are all vivid representations of actual animals, including armadillos. Yet armadillos are native only to the Americas, and van Eyck died decades before Europeans reached the Americas.
question: Explain why the two highlighted portions of the argument do not serve the roles of the first being a judgment that serves as the basis for the main conclusion of the argument and the second stating that main conclusion.
answer0: Yes the whole point of the passage is the conclusion in the first portion; and the second gives the irrefutable evidence for that conclusion.
answer1: The first is not an intermediate conclusion, it is final and contradicts the evidence of the previous sentence; and the second gives the proof for the final conclusion.
answer2: The first is the main conclusion itself; and the second proves it.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.option: The first is a judgment that serves as the basis for the main conclusion of the argument; the second states that main conclusion.

context: Rita: No matter how you look at them, your survey results are misleading. Since people generally lie on such surveys, the numbers you collected are serious underestimates. While the raw numbers surely underestimate what I' m trying to measure, the relative rates those numbers represent are probably close to being accurate.

context: In polluted industrial English cities during the Industrial Revolution, two plant diseases -- black spot, which infects roses, and tar spot, which infects sycamore trees -- disappeared. It is likely that air pollution eradicated these diseases.
question: What is the reason for why the fact that scientists theorize that some plants can develop a resistance to air pollution does not strengthen the reasoning?
answer0: Plants building up a resistance to air pollution would not impact air pollution's effect on diseases.
answer1: The effects of air pollution on plants wasn't being discussed, it was the effects of air pollution on diseases.
answer2: The author stated that it is likely that air pollution eradicated these diseases, so a lack of air pollution would bring the diseases back.
answer3: The author stated that these two diseases disappeared, but attributed it specifically to the increased air pollution.

context: It is wrong to waste our natural resources, and it is an incredible waste of resources to burn huge amounts of trash in incinerators. When trash is recycled, fewer resources are wasted. Because less trash will be recycled if an incinerator is built, the city should not build an incinerator.
question: Why is it not valid to infer that by recycling more trash, the city can stop wasting resources entirely based on the statements above?
answer0: According to the passage recycling more trash will help cut back on the amount of resources being wasted, but nowhere does it tell us that it will put a stop to resources being wasted entirely.
answer1: Recycling trash does conserve resources according to the passage, but nowhere in the passage does it tell the reader that it is the most effective method in which to conserve.
answer2: This can be inferred because the passage states that when large amounts of trash is burned in an incinerator it wastes resources because items are not being recycled.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: If a civilization as technologically advanced as human civilization existed on another planet and that planet were within 50 light years of Earth, that civilization would have found evidence of intelligent life on Earth and could have easily contacted us. Scientists can thus rule out the possibility of finding a civilization as technologically advanced as our own within 50 light years of Earth.
question: What is the basis for the argument not requiring the assumption that there is no reason to doubt the possibility that there are technologically advanced civilizations on planets more than 50 light years from Earth?
answer0: This assumption is required for the argument that if a civilization is within 50 light years of us, it would have by definition contacted us.  This presupposes that it would want to contact us, and not avoid us for some reason.
answer1: There is a difference in what this response proposes, scientists actively seeking life forms, which could be technologically advanced or not, and what the statement above proposes, which is that we would be passive recipients, receiving contact from another civilization.
answer2: A civilization, whether it is  within 50 light years or farther away, could have many reasons to contact us, or not contact us.  Making this an absolute statement can't be supported.
answer3: There is no way to confirm that an intelligent species can recognize other intelligent species.  For many years, people thought humans of different races were inferior, so why would a totally different species not view us as a non-intelligent species?

context: Trainer: I recently developed an exercise routine that can get anybody to meet his or her goals. The routine combines cardio and bodybuilding during each session for the purpose of losing weight. Every person I' ve trained has lost weight on the program.
question: How does the fact that every client the trainer has worked with has weight loss as a goal affect the strength of the argument?
answer0: There was no mention of diet here. The trainer said they could meet their goals with cardio and bodybuilding. We can not know if they worked out more to counteract a bad diet, or had a good diet. We only know that the trainer used cardio and bodybuilding and all the clients lost weight.
answer1: The text does not mention the health of the clients either before or after losing weight. It only mentions losing weight. So we can not know if they got healthy after losing weight.
answer2: There is no mention of how mush exercise experience any one has had prior to seeing the trainer.
answer3: The text states that the trainer can get anyone to meet their goals and every person they have trained have lost weight. There is no mention of achieving any other goal, therefore all their clients must have wanted to lose weight.

context: Many important types of medicine have been developed from substances discovered in plants that grow only in tropical rain forests. There are thousands of plant species in these rain forests that have not yet been studied by scientists, and it is very likely that many such plants also contain substances of medicinal value. Thus, if the tropical rain forests are not preserved, important types of medicine will never be developed.
question: What is the basis for the argument not requiring the assumption that most of the tropical rain forest plants that contain substances of medicinal value can also be found growing in other types of environment?
answer0: It is not necessary for any and all substances of medicinal value to be discovered, the discovery of a limited number could still be valuable.
answer1: That tropical rain forests should be preserved to make it possible for important medicines to be developed from plant species that have not yet been studied is explicit to the argument, it is not an assumption.
answer2: If substances of medicinal value can also be found growing in other types of environment then the argument that it is necessary to preserve rain forests in order to obtain these substances is weakened, not strengthened.
answer3: If the substances that have not yet been discovered are no different from those that have been discovered then it would weaken the author's argument that it is important to be able to discover them.

main_question.option: Most of the tropical rain forest plants that contain substances of medicinal value can also be found growing in other types of environment.

context: Ancient humans in eastern North America hunted mammoths until the mammoth disappeared from the area around 13, 000 years ago. question: What evidence is needed to demonstrate that the argument does not depend on the assumption that the fossil on which the engraving was made was not a mammoth bone?
answer0: The passage does not give us information regarding where all mammoths were thought to have lived in this time 13,000 years ago.
answer1: This can be assumed from the passage because a person had to have seen mammoths before in order to be able to engrave the likeness of a mammoth on the fossil.
answer2: The assumption that the bone found with the engraving was any specific bone cannot be made from the passage as it does not inform the reader as to what kind of bone it was other than being a fossil.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.option: the fossil on which the engraving was made was not a mammoth bone

context: Blogger: Traditionally, newspapers have taken objectivity to be an essential of good journalism . However, today' s newer media are more inclined to try to create a stir with openly partisan reporting. This contrast in journalistic standards is best understood in terms of differing business strategies. The newer media outlets need to differentiate themselves in a crowded marketplace. The standard of objectivity developed primarily among newspapers with no serious rivals, so the most important objective was to avoid offending potential readers.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the blogger's argument does not require the assumption that journalists at traditional newspapers are just as partisan as journalists who work for newer media outlets?
answer0: It's implied in the passage that the old media are well established, and the newer media are having to put in extra effort to stand out of the crowd.
answer1: While the passage stated the newspapers were trying to avoid readers by being objective, it gives no information on whether or not people actually prefer one or the other.
answer2: Since objectivism is seen as good journalism, people by far would be more likely to consume objective media.
answer3: The old journalists came to be with no major competitors, so they never had to become partisan to attract consumers like some new media journalists may have had to.

main_question.context: Blogger: Traditionally, newspapers have taken objectivity to be an essential of good journalism . However, today' s newer media are more inclined to try to create a stir with openly partisan reporting. This contrast in journalistic standards is best understood in terms of differing business strategies. The newer media outlets need to differentiate themselves in a crowded marketplace. The standard of objectivity developed primarily among newspapers with no serious rivals, so the most important objective was to avoid offending potential readers.
main_question.question: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the blogger's argument?
main_question.option: Journalists at traditional newspapers are just as partisan as journalists who work for newer media outlets.

context: The difference in average annual income in favor of employees who have college degrees, compared with those who do not have such degrees, doubled between 1980 and 1990. Some analysts have hypothesized that increased competition between employers for employees with college degrees drove up income for such employees.
question: Explain why the fact that during the 1980s there were some employees with no college degree who earned incomes comparable to the top incomes earned by employees with a college degree does not seriously undermine the explanation described above.
answer0: The average age of all employees overall does not tell us anything about the increase in income among those with college degrees during the same period of time.
answer1: If college graduates are required to take unskilled jobs because they cannot find one requiring a college degree, then the increase in wages among college graduates is not the result of employer competition for college graduates because there are more graduates than employers.
answer2: The fact that some employees with no college degree earned an income comparable to some employees with a college degree does not tell us anything about the overall increase in the incomes of all employees with college degrees.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.context: The difference in average annual income in favor of employees who have college degrees, compared with those who do not have such degrees, doubled between 1980 and 1990. main_question.question: Which of the following, if true, most seriously undermines the explanation described above?
main_question.option: During the 1980s there were some employees with no college degree who earned incomes comparable to the top incomes earned by employees with a college degree.

answer1: If college graduates are required to take unskilled jobs because they cannot find one requiring a college degree, then the increase in wages among college graduates is not the result of employer competition for college graduates because there are more graduates than employers.
answer2: The average age of all employees overall does not tell us anything about the increase in income among those with college degrees during the same period of time.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Editorial: It is clear that if this country' s universities were living up to both their moral and their intellectual responsibilities, the best-selling publications in most university bookstores would not be frivolous ones like TV Today and Gossip Review. However, in most university bookstores the only publication that sells better than Gossip Review is TV Today.
question: What is the reasoning for concluding that, on the basis of the statements, at least some of this country's universities are not meeting their moral responsibilities or their intellectual responsibilities or both?
answer0: The editorial suggests that it is morally and/or intellectually irresponsible for universities to have created a moral and intellectual environment where frivolous publications are the most popular, but it does not make any claims about whether merely carrying such publications is irresponsible.
answer1: The editorial makes a claim about the moral and intellectual responsibilities of universities, but says nothing about the moral and intellectual responsibilities of individuals who attend these universities.
answer2: The best-selling publications in university bookstores are frivolous ones like TV Today and Gossip Review, so based on the editorial, this country's universities cannot be living up to both their moral and intellectual responsibilities.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.question: If the statements in the editorial are true, which one of the following must also be true on the basis of them?
main_question.option: At least some of this country's universities are not meeting their moral responsibilities or their intellectual responsibilities or both.

context: One good clue as to which geographical regions an ancient relic was moved through in the past involves the analysis of pollen that clings to the surface of the relic. A relic is linked to a geographical area by the identification of pollen from plants that are known to have been unique to that area.
question: How does the fact that pollens are often transported from one region to another by wind or human movement cast doubt on the reliability of the method described above?
answer0: The difficulty and expense associated with a method does not imply it is not a useful or accurate method.
answer1: If pollen is not specific to an area and can be moved, then it would be an unreliable measure to determine if something was from a specific area based on pollen content since it could change over time and be in places it did not originate.
answer2: While the same kind of pollen being found in more than one area would make it a less specific measure for an items place of origin, it would still narrow the area down to some degree.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.context: One good clue as to which geographical regions an ancient relic was moved through in the past involves the analysis of pollen that clings to the surface of the relic. main_question.question: Which one of the following, if true, casts the most doubt on the reliability of the method described above?
main_question.option: Pollens are often transported from one region to another by wind or human movement.

context: The tendency toward overspecialization in the study of artifacts is unfortunate. Scholars can enhance their understanding of a certain artistic period by studying art from earlier periods that had a significant influence on it. For instance, because of its influence on Spanish artisans, a proper understanding of Arabic porcelain is indispensable for a proper understanding of Spanish porcelain.
question: Why does the principle that the passage as a whole illustrates not closely conform to the claim that to appreciate fully the French language, one must understand the other languages that share its linguistic ancestry?
answer0: The passage maintains that a full understanding of a historical topic requires an understanding of earlier historical influences, and Plato's philosophy was a direct historical influence on Aristotle's philosophy.
answer1: The passage emphasizes that full understanding of something requires understanding of its historical influences, so it would maintain that to fully appreciate the French language, one must understand its linguistic ancestry, not specifically other languages that share its linguistic ancestry.
answer2: The passage emphasizes that full understanding of something requires understanding of its historical influences, but similar events in earlier centuries do not necessarily influence events of this century.
answer3: The passage emphasizes that full understanding of something requires understanding of its historical influences, but the practices of the wider academic community are not necessarily historical influences on an academic discipline.

context: Studies suggest that, for the vast majority of people who have normal blood pressure, any amount of sodium greater than that required by the body is simply excreted and does not significantly raise blood pressure. So only persons who have high blood pressure and whose bodies are incapable of safely processing excess sodium need to restrict their sodium intake.
question: Explain why the fact that every human being has a physiological need for at least some sodium does not weaken the argument.
answer0: According to the test there is a required amount of sodium for people. This strengthens the argument for decreasing sodium intake since we all need a minimum amount. Going over that minimum amount is harmful for some people.
answer1: It would not matter how harmful high blood pressure is, the recommendation is to help people with blood pressure, no matter how harmful it is.
answer2: This would weaken the argument that only people who can not process the excess sodium should decrease their consumption. If excess sodium will eventually destroy the body's ability to secrete it, then that is true for all people. According to that, all people should decrease sodium intake.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.question: Which one of the following, if true, would most seriously weaken the argument?
main_question.option: Every human being has a physiological need for at least some sodium.

context: In a few recent cases, some teenagers with advanced programming abilities used a new programming language, FANTOD, to hack into ETS and change their own SAT scores. All of the teenagers convicted of this crime were highly skilled in programming FANTOD. In light of these cases, some colleges have discounted the official SAT scores of applicants with a knowledge of FANTOD, and have required them to take special admission tests in supervised conditions on their own campuses.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that students who learn FANTOD tend to have much lower SAT scores than do their peers based on the information given?
answer0: The passage just states that some colleges are requiring additional tests it does not suggest that colleges should completely rely on their own tests.
answer1: Students who learn FANTOD have advanced programming abilities but this does not show or prove that they have lower SAT scores.
answer2: It is not correct to assume that all who learn to program FANTOD are doing so to commit a crime.  The passage stated that that some used this.  it does not reference all.
answer3: Students who have knowledge of FANTOD are at a disadvantage as they are being subjected to extra scrutiny and may even have to  take special tests to prove they are capable of the scores that they are getting.

main_question.context: In a few recent cases, some teenagers with advanced programming abilities used a new programming language, FANTOD, to hack into ETS and change their own SAT scores. All of the teenagers convicted of this crime were highly skilled in programming FANTOD. In light of these cases, some colleges have discounted the official SAT scores of applicants with a knowledge of FANTOD, and have required them to take special admission tests in supervised conditions on their own campuses.
main_question.question: Which of following conclusions can most properly be drawn from the information above?
main_question.option: Students who learn FANTOD tend to have much lower SAT scores than do their peers.

context: Dr. Theresa Pagano, a biologist, has found that the checkerspot butterfly is becoming more prevalent in regions farther north than before and less prevalent in regions farther south. The northward shift of the butterflies is almost perfectly correlated with the northward shift of the warm zones in the global climate, and Dr. Pagano has ttherefore concluded that the changing climate is responsible for the northward movement of the butterflies.
question: Why does the experimental evidence suggesting that the checkerspot butterfly can adapt easily to a wide range of temperatures and geographic conditions not support Dr. Pagano's reasoning?
answer0: If the warm zones are shifting northward due to climate change, the plants the butterfly relies on would also gradually shift northward, leaving fewer to none of these plants in the southern regions for the butterflies to depend on.
answer1: Those same small temperature changes that critically affect the checkerspot butterfly in the lab would also affect the butterfly as climate zones shift northward.
answer2: If the checkerspot butterfly can easily adapt to a wide range of temperatures, it would make more sense for the butterfly to both shift northward as well as remain in place.
answer3: One would expect that if species very similar to the checkerspot butterfly only survive in warm climates, the same would be true of the checkerspot butterfly as well.

context: Scientists conjecture that certain microbes consume organic molecules in exposed shale and similar sediments. context: A number of Grandville' s wealthiest citizens have been criminals. So, since it is of utmost importance that the Grandville Planning Committee be composed solely of individuals whose personal standards of ethics are beyond reproach, no wealthy person should be appointed to that committee.
question: Why is the argument not considered to be flawed for judging something that can be readily evaluated according to objective standards only by subjective standards?
answer0: It is objectively true whether or not a citizen has been a criminal, not subjective.

answer2: The argument that the result (an ethical committee) can be achieved by only by not selecting wealthy people is false, since non-wealthy people can be unethical
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Sociologist: Marriage is one of the most important societal institutions. Marital relationship provides numerous structural benefits for married couples and their offspring. Studies consistently show that children born out of wedlock are less likely to attend college and more likely to work low-paying jobs. Additionally, married people are more likely to be homeowners and save for retirement. Ttherefore, if marriage rates decline, __.
question: Explain why the conclusion that nobody would own homes does not logically complete the sociologist's argument.
answer0: The passage states that married people are more likely to own homes, but not that they are the only people that own homes. Many single and even divorced people can and do own homes.
answer1: The passage states that children whose parents are married are more likely to attend college, so it reasons that fewer marriages will result in fewer people attending college.
answer2: The study does not mentioned happiness rates among people who are not married and people who are married. Married and single people can be happy and unhappy so happiness is not a good indication of an anything in the study.
answer3: The passage focuses upon positives and negatives associated with being married and not being married, but nowhere does it go into something as devastating and serious as society falling apart or collapsing.

context: People often admonish us to learn the lessons of history, but, even if it were easy to discover what the past was really like, it is nearly impossible to discover its lessons. We are supposed, for example, to learn the lessons of World War I. But what are they? And were we ever to discover what they are, it is not clear that we could ever apply them, for we shall never again have a situation just like World War I.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the claim that we should learn the lessons of history appears in a way that is compatible with both accepting and denying the argument's conclusion?
answer0: The author's conclusions are contrary to the assumption that we should learn the lessons of history.
answer1: The author argues that it is not possible to learn the lessons of history, that we should learn the lessons of history is only compatible with denying this.
answer2: The position that we should learn the lessons of history is argued against in specific ways by the author.
answer3: The author does not take this position for granted but gives specific reasons they disagree with it.

context: Every week, the programming office at an FM radio station reviewed unsolicited letters from listeners who were expressing comments on the station' s programs. One week, the station received 50 letters with favorable comments about the station' s news reporting and music selection and 10 letters with unfavorable comments on the station' s new movie review segment of the evening program. Faced with this information, the programming director assumed that if some listeners did not like the movie review segment, then there must be other listeners who did like it. Ttherefore, he decided to continue the movie review segment of the evening program.
question: What is the basis for identifying a problem with the programming director's decision process due to his inability to properly infer from the fact that some listeners did not like the movie review segment that some others did?
answer0: The programming director's argument relies on the notion that people are more likely to criticize than to praise, because there was no praise of the movie review segment.
answer1: No one wrote a positive comment on the movie review segment, not even the people who praised other segments, which could mean that no one liked it.
answer2: The director's argument relies on comments not written, so would apply no matter how many or few unfavorable comments the station received.
answer3: Assuming there is a relationship between the news and movie review segments would actually bolster the director's arguments, since all the news comments were positive.

context: After a nuclear power plant accident, researchers found radioactive isotopes of iodine, tellurium, and cesium-but no heavy isotopes-in the atmosphere downwind. This material came either from spent fuel rods or from the plant' s core. Spent fuel rods never contain significant quantities of tellurium isotopes. Radioactive material ejected into the atmosphere directly from the core would include heavy isotopes. After the accident, steam, which may have been in contact with the core, was released from the plant. The core contains iodine, tellurium, and cesium isotopes, which are easily dissolved by steam.
question: What is the evidence that suggests that the statement that the nuclear power plant's spent fuel rods were not damaged is not strongly supported by the information above?
answer0: There were no heavy isotopes which would have been present if ejected from the core.
answer1: Because tellurium never occurs from spent fuel rods, the assertion that radioactive material was carried by steam is supported since they are dissolved in steam which is still left as a possible explanation for their presence after an accident.
answer2: Fuel rods are mentioned being spent.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Science writer: The deterioration of cognitive faculties associated with Alzheimer' s disease is evidently caused by the activities of microglia -- the brain' s own immune cells. For one thing, this deterioration can be slowed by some anti-inflammatory drugs, such as acetylsalicylic acid. Furthermore, patients with Alzheimer' s are unable to eliminate the protein BA from the brain, where it accumulates and forms deposits. The microglia attack these protein deposits by releasing poisons that destroy surrounding healthy brain cells, thereby impairing the brain' s cognitive functions.
question: How does the fact that acetylsalicylic acid reduces the production of immune cells in the brain support the science writer's argument?
answer0: Reactions of microglia in other diseases is not necessarily relevant to their involvement in Alzheimer's.
answer1: Immune cells are produced in the brain in Alzheimer's patients as a result of protein deposits so reducing the inflammation from these deposits could lead to less immune response and therefore, less tissue damage since the immune response destroys surrounding tissue, leading to a decline in cognitive function.
answer2: While problems with eliminating BA is a deficiency in Alzheimer's patients, reducing the immune response to the BA is what would be addressed with Acetylsalicylic acid.
answer3: While this is the reason it is important to address the immune system that results from the buildup of BA, it is the response that affects cognitive function by destroying the surrounding tissue in response.

main_question.option: Acetylsalicylic acid reduces the production of immune cells in the brain.

context: Lack of exercise produces the same or similar bodily effects as aging. In fact, the physical changes that accompany aging can often be slowed down by appropriate exercise. No drug, however, holds any promise for slowing down the changes associated with aging. Ttherefore, __.
question: Why does the fact that people who do not exercise when they are young will gain few benefits from beginning to exercise at a later age not provide a logical completion to the passage?
answer0: Since drugs do not slow the physical changes associated with aging and exercise does do this, this option is true and a natural conclusion to the passage, which makes both points.
answer1: Since the passage points out that drugs do NOT slow the physical changes associated with aging, adding drugs to exercise will not help and so this option is false and not a natural conclusion to the passage.
answer2: Aging can be slowed down by exercise no matter when in life you start exercising, so this option is false and thus not a natural conclusion to the passage.
answer3: Appropriate exercise can't prevent the physical changes associated with aging; it can only slow them down, so this option is false and thus not a natural conclusion to the passage.

main_question.option: people who do not exercise when they are young will gain few benefits from beginning to exercise at a later age

context: Economist: A country' s trade deficit may indicate weakness in its economy, but it does not in itself weaken that economy. So restricting imports to reduce a trade deficit would be like sticking a thermometer into a glass of cold water in the hope of bringing down a patient' s feverish temperature.
question: Why does the economist's argument not employ the technique of demonstrating that an analogy explicitly used to establish a certain conclusion is faulty?
answer0: The passage compares the sign of a weakened economy to that of a glass of water. It is showing why this will not work through comparison.
answer1: The passage does not suggest that any bad consequences will happen.
answer2: This passage does not use an analogy to prove a conclusion is faulty, it uses it to make a point.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Huang: Most people who commit violent crimes do not carefully consider whether or how they will be punished for these crimes. And those who don' t commit violent crimes have no inclination to do so. Rather than impose harsh mandatory sentences, we should attend to the root causes of violence to reduce the rate of violent crime. Suarez: Would you say the same about nonviolent crimes, such as tax evasion? Surely mandatory penalties are a useful deterrent in these cases. At any rate, I am confident that mandatory sentences prevent most people who would otherwise physically harm others from doing so.
question: What evidence from the dialogue between Huang and Suarez supports the claim that they disagree about whether mandatory sentences will deter most people who might otherwise commit violent crimes?
answer0: While Huang states that the best way to reduce violent crime is to address the root causes of violence, Suarez does not take a stance on addressing the root causes of violence; the issue both Huang and Suarez address directly is mandatory sentencing.
answer1: Only Suarez mentions penalties for nonviolent crimes such as tax evasion; the main conversation and issue that both Suarez and Huang address is sentencing for violent crime.
answer2: Huang states that they believe that people who commit violent crimes do not carefully consider the consequences, but Suarez does not address this directly and so it is not the focus of their conversation.
answer3: Suarez states that they are confident that mandatory sentences prevent physical harm in most cases, while Huang states that they believe people who commit violent crimes do not consider the consequences.

context: Public health will improve more quickly in the wake of new medical discoveries if medical researchers abandon their practice of waiting until their findings are published in peer-reviewed journals before informing the press of important research results. This is because the public release of new medical information allows people to use that information in order to improve their health, but the peer-review process is unavoidably very slow.
question: Why is it valid to conclude that the argument depends on the assumption that people would use new medical information even if it were not first published in peer-reviewed journals?
answer0: The passage is not focused on speeding up the peer-review process, rather upon releasing findings to the public immediately in an effort to allow people to use new information to better their health. Even if this statement were true, the passage is not focused upon speeding up this process.
answer1: This statement reiterates the point of the passage by stating that the public would use findings immediately in an effort to better their health even if the findings had not been published in peer-reviewed journals.
answer2: This goes against the passage because right now the information and findings that is published in the journals does receive public attention, but the goal is to speed this process up by eliminating the public having to wait until such information becomes published.
answer3: The passage does not delve into whether or not medical journal reviewers are also medical researchers or not and this information has no bearing upon the argument of the importance of releasing research findings to the public immediately.

context: Ninety percent of recent car buyers say safety was an important factor in their purchase. Yet of these car buyers, only half consulted objective sources of vehicle safety information before making their purchase; the others relied on advertisements and promotional materials. Thus, these other buyers were mistaken in saying that safety was important to them.
question: Why does the argument's conclusion not logically follow even if it is assumed that most consumers are aware that advertisements and promotional materials are not objective sources of vehicle safety information?
answer0: If consumers were aware of how lacking in vehicle safety information the promotional materials were, they would make more of an effort to do independent research if they were genuine.
answer1: If someone is really obsessed with purchasing the most safe vehicle for his or her family, they would take the extra step in doing more than surface research on the safety of the vehicle.
answer2: Even if the safety information in the promotional materials is incomplete, that would have no bearing on whether or not the person was sincere in their concern about vehicle safety.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.context: Ninety percent of recent car buyers say safety was an important factor in their purchase. main_question.question: The argument's conclusion follows logically if which one of the following is assumed?
main_question.option: Most consumers are aware that advertisements and promotional materials are not objective sources of vehicle safety information.

context: The caterpillar of the monarch butterfly feeds on milkweed plants, whose toxins make the adult monarch poisonous to many predators. The viceroy butterfly, whose caterpillars do not feed on milkweed plants, is very similar in appearance to the monarch. Ttherefore, it can be concluded that the viceroy is so seldom preyed on because of its visual resemblance to the monarch.
question: Explain why the fact that some of the predators of the monarch butterfly also prey on viceroys does not seriously undermine the argument.
answer0: If the viceroy is toxic to most predators then looking like a less toxic butterfly, such as the monarch, would not decrease the likelihood of it not being preyed on so much as it would likely be decreased by its own association with toxicity.
answer1: If there was no reaction to the toxin there would be no reason for a predator to avoid a food source with the toxin in it.
answer2: Monarch and viceroy butterflies would have to have common predators if the assumption is that those predators are deterred due the appearance of the butterflies being similar.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Sociologists study folktales because they provide a means of understanding the distinctive values of a culture. However, the folktales in almost all cultures are adaptations of the same ancient narratives to the local milieu.
question: How does the fact that the ancient narratives persist largely because they speak to basic themes and features of the human condition help to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the information above?
answer0: The absence of a single author does not necessarily mean that a folktale will reflect the values of a specific culture, because it could be reflecting values that are common to all cultures.
answer1: Although most folktales have their origins in the same ancient sources, the different ways in which they have evolved over time provides information about what different cultures have found to be most important and worth remembering.
answer2: Whether a folktale is written or survives from oral traditions does not tell us anything about why it might reflect the values of a specific culture.
answer3: The fact that folktales speak to basic themes of the human condition does not explain why sociologists would study them to understand the distinct values of a culture.

context: If cold fusion worked, it would provide almost limitless power from very inexpensive raw materials, materials far cheaper than coal or oil. But replacing all the traditional electric generators that use these fuels with cold-fusion power plants would result in a reduction of no more than 25 percent in the average residential electric bill.
question: Why would the fact that personnel costs for the distribution of power to consumers are unrelated to the type of raw materials an electric company uses help to resolve the apparent discrepancy between the predictions above?
answer0: Even though the cost of raw materials for cold fusion would be very inexpensive the limited savings for consumers could relate to personnel costs.
answer1: The higher costs of building and maintaining cold-fusion power plants would offset other savings.
answer2: If companies were willing to use cold-fusion it would be expected that there would be a more significant reduction in costs for users due to the inexpensive materials used in cold fusion.
answer3: Although the fuel for cold-fusion would be cheaper this only represents a small portion of residential electric bills.

context: A university study reported that between 1975 and 1983 the length of the average workweek in a certain country increased significantly. A governmental study, on the other hand, shows a significant decline in the length of the average workweek for the same period. Examination of the studies shows, however, that they used different methods of investigation; thus there is no need to look further for an explanation of the difference in the studies' results.
question: Why is the argument's reasoning not considered to be invalid due to its failure to acknowledge that varying economic conditions result in the average workweek changing in length?
answer0: It does not fail to distinguish the different studies, it blatantly says that one study was a university and one was by the government.
answer1: This passage does not mention anything about vetting economic conditions.
answer2: Just because in this circumstance the results were different and the methodology was different does not ensure that will always be the case.
answer3: The purpose is not important here, it is the difference between two studies that is the topic at hand.

context: Boreal owls range over a much larger area than do other owls of similar size. The reason for this behavior is probably that the small mammals on which owls feed are especially scarce in the forests where boreal owls live, and the relative scarcity of prey requires the owls to range more extensively to find sufficient food.
question: Why does the fact that the boreal owl requires less food, relative to its weight, than is required by members of other owl species not help to confirm the explanation above?
answer0: If the size of ranges for this particular species of owl varies depending on the scarcity or abundance of prey, it stands to reason that this rationale would apply to the differences between this species and others as well.
answer1: The difference in size between the size of different owls' ranges would not confirm whether a lack of prey is the cause of the disparity.
answer2: If anything, this would contradict the explanation given that requiring less food would suggest that these owls would not need to range as extensively to get adequate sustenance.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.context: Boreal owls range over a much larger area than do other owls of similar size. main_question.option: The boreal owl requires less food, relative to its weight, than is required by members of other owl species.

context: John: There have been complaints about the lack of parks in our city. Some people favor turning the old airport land into biking and hiking trails, but there may be more productive ways of using that land. Pablo: But the old airport land is ideal for biking and hiking trails. Our citizens have gone too long with an inadequate number of parks; we should not dismiss this proposal for biking and hiking trails without further consideration.
question: What is the evidence that Pablo did not interpret John to be claiming that it may not be possible to convert the old airport land into adequate biking and hiking results?
answer0: Pablo is arguing with John that the land is best used to make the trails while John argues it may not be the best, neither are arguing that it is not possible to make the land into trails.
answer1: John makes no alternative park ideas, only stating the land may be used for something else than biking and hiking trails, so Pablo sees it as John being against the latter, not for any other park ideas.
answer2: Pablo argues with John that the idea of biking and hiking trails on the land is ideal and should not dismiss the idea, this shows that he believes John doesn't want to continue with the idea of using the land made for biking and hiking trails.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Psychologist: Identical twins are virtually the same genetically. Moreover, according to some studies, identical twins separated at birth and brought up in vastly different environments show a strong tendency to report similar ethical beliefs, dress in the same way, and have similar careers. Thus, many of our inclinations must be genetic in origin, and not subject to environmental influences.
question: Explain why the fact that scientists are far from being able to link any specific genes to specific inclinations does not weaken the psychologist's argument.
answer0: The author offers observation that science practitioners have yet to connect specific gene types to specific choices or preferences, overall.
answer1: The author compares contextual difference in Nature versus Nurture, here stating that reveal that identically genetic people, are similar in some traits, and different in others.
answer2: The author compares "Nature versus Nurture" and extends or flips the initial comparison - difference in belief categories, can occur in same genetic people, identical people physically. By comparison, identical people in identical environments are different also.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Frobisher, a sixteenth-century English explorer, had soil samples from Canada' s Kodlunarn Island examined for gold content. Because high gold content was reported, Elizabeth I funded two mining expeditions. Neither expedition found any gold there. Modern analysis of the island' s soil indicates a very low gold content. Thus the methods used to determine the gold content of Frobisher' s samples must have been inaccurate.
question: Explain why the argument does not depend on the assumption that the two mining expeditions funded by Elizabeth I did not mine the same part of Kodlunarn Island?
answer0: Whether the two expeditions mined the same part of Kodlunarn Island for gold is not relevant to whether or not the soil-testing methods were accurate.
answer1: The gold content of the soil today on Kodlunarn Island does not necessarily reflect its gold content in the sixteenth century.
answer2: If Frobisher had added gold to the soil samples before they were examined, then the tests would be accurate but the results falsified.
answer3: There is no evidence that the accuracy of the soil-testing method depends on having samples from other Canadian islands to examine for gold content.

context: Announcement for a television program: Are female physicians more sensitive than male physicians to the needs of women patients? To get the answer, we' ll ask physicians of both sexes this question. Tune in tomorrow.
question: Explain why the fact that there still are fewer women than men who are physicians does not identify a flaw in the plan for the program?
answer0: Questioning the physicians about whether they are more helpful to female patients does not actually answer the question of whether they are helpful to the female patients; you have to question the patients to get an accurate answer to this question. answer1: That physicians don't discuss the treatment style of other physicians has nothing to do with their discussing their helpfulness to women patients, so this option is irrelevant to the passage and therefore does not point out a flaw in it.

context: Many people change their wills on their own every few years, in response to significant changes in their personal or financial circumstances. This practice can create a problem for the executor when these people are careless and do not date their wills: the executor will then often know neither which one of several undated wills is the most recent, nor whether the will drawn up last has ever been found. Ttherefore, people should not only date their wills but also state in any new will which will it supersedes, for then there would not be a problem to begin with.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument considered flawed for treating a partial solution to the stated problem as though it were a complete solution?
answer0: The proposed solution of will dating does in fact solve one aspect of the problem (relative recency of wills), and makes no mention of any other parties being involved.
answer1: Dating the will would solve the problem of determining it's relative recency, but would not establish whether or not the most recent will had been found, contrary to the claim made by the argument.
answer2: The argument makes no mention of containing adverse effects, merely enumerating two of them.
answer3: None of the above choices
