context: When a polygraph test is judged inconclusive, this is no reflection on the examinee. Rather, such a judgment means that the test has failed to show whether the examinee was truthful or untruthful. Nevertheless, employers will sometimes refuse to hire a job applicant because of an inconclusive polygraph test result.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that most examinees with inconclusive polygraph test results are in fact untruthful based on the information given?
answer0: Employers may refuse to hire job applicants due to inconclusive polygraph test results, but there is no indication that employers have refused to use polygraph test results for hiring purposes.
answer1: An inconclusive polygraph test result does not indicate anything about the examinee, so refusing to hire such an examinee on the basis of their polygraph test result is unfair.
answer2: Inclusive polygraph test results do not indicate anything about the examinees, including how truthful they are as a whole.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.context: When a polygraph test is judged inconclusive, this is no reflection on the examinee. main_question.question: Which of the following conclusions can most properly be drawn from the information above?
main_question.option: Most examinees with inconclusive polygraph test results are in fact untruthful.

context: City council member: Despite the city' s desperate need to exploit any available source of revenue, the mayor has repeatedly blocked council members' attempts to pass legislation imposing real estate development fees. It is clear that in doing so the mayor is sacrificing the city' s interests to personal interests. The mayor cites figures to show that, in the current market, fees of the size proposed would significantly reduce the number of building starts and thus, on balance, result in a revenue loss to the city. But the important point is that the mayor' s family is heavily involved in real estate development and thus has a strong financial interest in the matter.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the main conclusion of the city council member's argument is that imposing real estate development fees is the best way for the city to exploit the available sources of revenue?
answer0: The argument mentions no other methods of exploiting sources of revenue and so does not address the relative importance of development fees.
answer1: The argument does not directly address whether the mayor's advancement of the contrary argument regarding the effect of reduced building starts is correct or not.
answer2: Financial interests by the mayor's family are asserted, but they are not the argument's main conclusion.
answer3: The argument concludes that the mayor's reluctance to impose development fees is due to his and his family's personal financial interest in the matter, due to them being impacted by such fees.

context: Physician: In itself, exercise does not cause heart attacks; rather, a sudden increase in an exercise regimen can be a cause. When people of any physical condition suddenly increase their amount of exercise, they also increase their risk of heart attack. As a result, there will be an increased risk of heart attack among employees of this company due to the new health program.
question: Why does the conclusion not logically follow even if it is assumed that all employees, no matter what their physical condition, will participate in the new health program?
answer0: Even if all the employees participated, the increased risk of heart attack would only happen if they suddenly increase their activity level. If everyone exercised at their current level then participating in the program will not lead to an increased risk of hear attack.
answer1: The text does not state if this is a sudden change by the company or if they are just changing health programs. Even if it is sudden, the suddenness of the program does not increase risk of heart attack- it is the sudden increase in actual exercise.
answer2: If an abrupt increase in exercise will increase the risk of heart attack, then an increase in heart attacks would happen with this new program because people suddenly increases their activity when they joined the program.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.context: Physician: In itself, exercise does not cause heart attacks; rather, a sudden increase in an exercise regimen can be a cause. When people of any physical condition suddenly increase their amount of exercise, they also increase their risk of heart attack. As a result, there will be an increased risk of heart attack among employees of this company due to the new health program.
main_question.question: The conclusion drawn by the physician follows logically if which one of the following is assumed?
main_question.option: All employees, no matter what their physical condition, will participate in the new health program.

context: Correctly measuring the productivity of service workers is complex. Consider, for example, postal workers: they are often said to be more productive if more letters are delivered per postal worker. But is this really true? What if more letters are lost or delayed per worker at the same time that more are delivered?
question: What is the reason for the objection not being based on doubts about the truth of the statement that postal workers are representative of service workers in general?
answer0: This is doubted to be true since the text determines instances when quality of services is ignored in determining productivity, but those quality is just as important as the other things counted in productivity.
answer1: This would not be in doubt since the argument uses postal workers as an example of how measuring productivity of service workers is not clear cut.
answer2: This is not called into doubt because the text offers the question about the letters that are delayed or not delivered. This implies that these pieces also relate to measuring productivity.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.question: The objection implied above to the productivity measure described is based on doubts about the truth of which of the following statements?
main_question.option: Postal workers are representative of service workers in general.

context: Correctly measuring the productivity of service workers is complex. What if more letters are lost or delayed per worker at the same time that more are delivered?
question: What is the basis for the objection implied above to the productivity measure described being based on doubts about the truth of the statement that the quality of services rendered can appropriately be ignored in computing productivity?
answer0: This would not be in doubt since the argument uses postal workers as an example of how measuring productivity of service workers is not clear cut.
answer1: This is doubted to be true since the text determines instances when quality of services is ignored in determining productivity, but those quality is just as important as the other things counted in productivity.
answer2: This is not called into doubt because the text offers the question about the letters that are delayed or not delivered. This implies that these pieces also relate to measuring productivity.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.context: Correctly measuring the productivity of service workers is complex. main_question.question: The objection implied above to the productivity measure described is based on doubts about the truth of which of the following statements?
main_question.option: The quality of services rendered can appropriately be ignored in computing productivity.

context: Studies in restaurants show that the tips left by customers who pay their bill in cash tend to be larger when the bill is presented on a tray that bears a credit card logo. Consumer psychologists hypothesize that simply seeing a credit-card logo makes many creditcard holders willing to spend more because it reminds them that their spending power exceeds the cash they have immediately available.
question: How does the fact that patrons who are under financial pressure from their credit-card obligations tend to tip less when presented with a restaurant bill on a tray with a credit-card logo than when the tray has no logo support the psychologists' interpretation of the studies?
answer0: This clearly indicates that an association exists between credit availability via credit card and the propensity (or otherwise) to spend cash on tips, strengthening the suggestion of such a relationship in the passage.
answer1: This indicates that credit availability via a credit card cannot be the sole motivating factor for increased spending on tips, as argued in the passage.
answer2: This strongly indicates that the patrons studied cannot have been motivated to spend more cash due to the availability of  credit via a credit card.
answer3: This indicates that use of a credit card in fact motivates patrons to leave smaller tips, contradicting the argument made in the passage.

main_question.context: Studies in restaurants show that the tips left by customers who pay their bill in cash tend to be larger when the bill is presented on a tray that bears a credit card logo. main_question.question: Which of the following, if true, most strongly supports the psychologists' interpretation of the studies?
main_question.option: Patrons who are under financial pressure from their credit-card obligations tend to tip less when presented with a restaurant bill on a tray with a credit-card logo than when the tray has no logo.

context: Gamba: Munoz claims that the Southwest Hopeville Neighbors Association overwhelmingly opposes the new water system, citing this as evidence of citywide opposition. answer1: Gamba asserts that Munoz's views have the declared support of less than 1% of one district of the city, and should not be generalised to a majority of the entire population of the city.
answer2: Gamba in fact questions both Munoz's assertion regarding the view of the Southwest Hopeville Neighbors Association AND his generalisation of this assertion to encompass the entire city.

context: Archaeologist: The allegation that members of the excavation team recovered artifacts outside the authorized site is unfounded. Archaeologists, unlike most treasure hunters, excavate artifacts to publish the results of their findings. But material recovered illegally could not be used in a publication without the illegal act being discovered. So it would be of no use to an archaeologist.
question: Why is the archaeologist's reasoning not considered to be flawed for presuming without evidence that most treasure hunters excavate artifacts to sell them?
answer0: The archaeologist's reasoning only provides a reason for why an archaeologist specifically would not recover artifacts illegally, and does not provide any rationale for why non-archaeologist members of the excavation team would not recover artifacts illegally.
answer1: The archaeologist does not fail to consider that not all treasure hunters act illegally, as they consider archaeologists to be treasure hunters and claim that archaeologists would not act illegally.
answer2: The archaeologist does not presume that most treasure hunters excavate artifacts to sell them.
answer3: The archaeologist does not assume that any use of illegally recovered material is itself illegal.

context: A public research facility should not patent its inventions. Such facilities, because they are supported by public funds, should encourage the free flow of ideas. A public research facility that retains the right to patent an invention has a motive to suppress the free flow of ideas in order to profit from the patent. Retaining the right to patent inventions is contrary to the public research facility' s obligation to do work intended for the benefit of the public.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the claim that a public research facility should not patent its inventions is later proven in the argument?
answer0: The writer aims to prove with supportive arguments, rather than to assume, the claim that public research facilities should not patent their inventions.
answer1: The claim that a public research facility should not patent its inventions serves as a conclusion which is supported by the reasons that follow, but not necessarily proven.
answer2: The claim that public research facilities should not patent their inventions is a conclusion drawn by the writer at the outset, and rather than follow a map the rest of the passage consists of supportive arguments for that conclusion.
answer3: The argument states at the beginning the conclusion that public research facilities should not patent inventions, and then provides supportive reasons explaining why doing so is contrary to the public interest.

context: In the paintings by seventeenth-century Dutch artist Vermeer, we find several recurrent items: a satin jacket, a certain Turkish carpet, and wooden chairs with lion' s head finials. These reappearing objects might seem to evince a dearth of props. Yet we know that many of the props Vermeer used were expensive. Thus, while we might speculate about exactly why Vermeer worked with a small number of familiar objects, it was clearly not for lack of props that the recurrent items were used.
question: Why does the conclusion follow logically if it is assumed that if a dearth of props accounted for the recurrent objects in Vermeer's paintings, we would not see expensive props in any of them?
answer0: If the satin jacket and wooden chairs in Vermeer's paintings were owned by his sister, then perhaps he couldn't afford to purchase props and had to borrow them.
answer1: Any props that were in Vermeer's studio would have been available for him to use, not just the ones seen in his paintings.
answer2: If Vermeer could afford to purchase the expensive items that are seen as props in his works, then he could certainly afford to purchase many inexpensive props as well.
answer3: If Vermeer was constantly including sentimental items in his paintings, then one could not assume that he didn't also own a lot of props that were not as important to him.

context: Bunty: The primary job of police officers is keeping the peace. Since their subsidiary jobs, such as controlling traffic, hinder their performance of the primary one, people other than police officers should be hired to perform the subsidiary jobs. Naina: To perform their primary job well, police officers must have the trust of citizens. They gain that trust by performing their subsidiary jobs, which are the only functions most citizens see them fulfill.
question: What is the reason for Bunty and Naina's disagreement about whether the subsidiary jobs police officers perform enable them to perform their primary job effectively?
answer0: Bunty states that the primary job of police officers is keeping peace, and Naina's argument implies agrement with this.
answer1: The disagreement is whether subsidiary jobs help officers gain the trust of citizens, not whether it is possible altogether.
answer2: Bunty believes that the subsidiary jobs hinder the performance of their primary job, while Naina believes that they gain trust, and thus are helped in the performance of primary duties, through subsidiary jobs.
answer3: While Naina argues that police officers need to win the trust of citizens to keep the peace, Bunty's argument does not imply any disagreement with this.

main_question.context: Bunty: The primary job of police officers is keeping the peace. Since their subsidiary jobs, such as controlling traffic, hinder their performance of the primary one, people other than police officers should be hired to perform the subsidiary jobs. Naina: To perform their primary job well, police officers must have the trust of citizens. They gain that trust by performing their subsidiary jobs, which are the only functions most citizens see them fulfill.

context: Ethicist: Studies have documented the capacity of placebos to reduce pain in patients who believe that they are receiving beneficial drugs. Some doctors say that they administer placebos because medically effective treatment reinforced by the placebo effect sometimes helps patients recover faster than good treatment alone. But administering placebos is nonetheless ethically questionable, for even if a placebo benefits a patient, a doctor might, for example, have prescribed it just to give the patient satisfaction that something was being done.
question: Why does the ethicist's argument not depend on the assumption that a patient's psychological satisfaction is not a consideration in administering medical treatment?
answer0: The ethicist specifically cites that sometimes, a patient's psychological satisfaction is a consideration in administering medical treatment, so the argument does not rely on an assumption that it is not a consideration.
answer1: The ethicist's conclusion is that administering placebos is ethically questionable, which is not supported by a claim that administering placebos is justified.
answer2: The ethicist states that the ethical questionability of placebo administration arises from the reason that the doctor had for prescribing a placebo, such as wanting to assure the patient that something was being done.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.context: Ethicist: Studies have documented the capacity of placebos to reduce pain in patients who believe that they are receiving beneficial drugs. Some doctors say that they administer placebos because medically effective treatment reinforced by the placebo effect sometimes helps patients recover faster than good treatment alone. But administering placebos is nonetheless ethically questionable, for even if a placebo benefits a patient, a doctor might, for example, have prescribed it just to give the patient satisfaction that something was being done.
main_question.question: The ethicist's argument depends on which one of the following assumptions?
main_question.option: A patient's psychological satisfaction is not a consideration in administering medical treatment.

context: Infants younger than six months who have normal hearing can readily distinguish between acoustically similar sounds that are used as part of any language -- not only those used in the language spoken by the people who raise them. Young adults can readily distinguish between such sounds only in languages that they regularly use. It is known that the physiological capacity to hear begins to deteriorate after infancy. So the observed difference in the abilities of infants and young adults to distinguish between acoustically similar speech sounds must be the result of the physiological deterioration of hearing.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument considered flawed for taking a factor that might contribute to an explanation of the observed difference as a sufficient explanation for that difference?
answer0: As the argument clearly ignores the possibility of neurological changes in the  brains of the participants with age contributing to the observed differences in perception, this characterisation of the reasoning is valid.
answer1: No references to any individuals within either group are made at any stage of the argument.
answer2: The cutoff point may have been arbitrary, but this does not invalidate any comparisons drawn between the two populations thus created.
answer3: This asserts a difference in data quality between measured populations without providing evidence for it, and as such is not relevant to the argument.

context: The formation of hurricanes that threaten the United States mainland is triggered by high atmospheric winds off the western coast of Africa. When abundant rain falls in sub-Saharan Africa, hurricanes afterward hit the United States mainland with particular frequency. Ttherefore, the abundant rains must somehow promote the ability of the winds to form hurricanes.
question: Explain why the argument that people who exercise vigorously tend to be healthy does not contain a flaw that is similar to one in the argument above.
answer0: The author states that a driving area with long city blocks, correlates with cars driving faster. Faster driving is assumed to be more dangerous for pedestrians, at least that is implied by author, more dangerous than shorter block areas.
answer1: The author states that a particular plant behaves one way in full sun exposure, and therefore must behave a polar or opposite way in night or no sun exposure. The assumption being that the flower must be open during a particular state of sun or no sun exposure.
answer2: Correlation is not causation, and here the author illustrates this by comparing different traits, financially independent success, correlating with college sports competition. To conclude that college competitive sports builds or emphasizes successful entrepreneurial capacity, may not be correct.
answer3: Author compares trait of regular vigorous exercise, to successful regular sleep. This then crosses another assumption, that vigorous exercisers, must be healthy, because perhaps people who regularly sleep, are healthy.

context: According to a prediction of the not-so-distant future published in 1940, electricity would revolutionize agriculture. Electrodes would be inserted into the soil, and the current between them would kill bugs and weeds and make crop plants stronger.
question: Why does the fact that in order for farmers to avoid electric shock while working in the fields, the current could be turned off at such times without diminishing the intended effects not strongly indicate that the logic of the prediction is flawed?
answer0: This shows a great flaw in the prediction and logo because weeds and crops are both types of plants and no explanation as to how the machine would know the difference between types of plants is given in the prediction.
answer1: This would support the prediction because it would take potential farmer or human injury or death out of the equation and make the prediction safer and easier to come true.
answer2: This also supports the prediction because it answers the question or concern as to how the planting machine and the electrodes would be able to safely interact and come into contact with one another. New parts would be designed to make this possible and safe.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Lactose, a sugar found in milk, aids in the absorption of calcium, which in turn is required for bone repair. In addition to there being shortages of milk in tropical areas, inhabitants of these areas lose the ability to absorb lactose, unlike people from nontropical areas. Yet inhabitants of tropical areas have no more problems with bone repair than do people who inhabit nontropical areas.
question: Explain why the fact that people living in tropical areas periodically take tablets containing lactose when there are shortages of milk does not help to resolve the apparent paradox described above.
answer0: The passage does not mention anything about taking lactose tablets.
answer1: Genetics are not mentioned to have an effect on lactose.
answer2: The passage does not mention anything about the amount of milk consumption.
answer3: This shows that something else in the body can aid in calcium absorption other than lactose.

context: In a recent poll of chief executive officers (CEOs) of 125 large corporations, the overwhelming majority claimed that employee training and welfare is of the same high priority as customer satisfaction. question: What is the rationale for why the argument is considered vulnerable to criticism for presuming, without giving justification, that the CEOs' claims are reflected in actual practice?

answer1: The CEOs may perceive that employee training and welfare are as important as customer satisfaction, but does not give examples of how CEOs actually implement these priorities.
answer2: The argument is based on a poll of 125 large-company CEOs, which is a pretty large sample.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.context: In a recent poll of chief executive officers (CEOs) of 125 large corporations, the overwhelming majority claimed that employee training and welfare is of the same high priority as customer satisfaction. So the popular belief that the top management of large corporations behaves indifferently to the needs and aspirations of employees is unfounded.
main_question.question: The argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that it
main_question.option: makes a generalization based on an unrepresentative sample

context: A very popular ice-cream shop recently raised the price of an ice-cream soda by $0. 20, from $1. 80 to $2. 00. Within a week of the price increase, all of the waiters-and waitresses had quit.
question: What is the reason for why the fact that the price increase allowed the shop to retain its popular generous portions of ice cream does not help to explain the resignations of the waiters and waitresses?
answer0: If regular customers still came into the shop, the demand stayed the same. If demand is the same, then the wait staff would have the same work expectations and same pay and would not need to quit.
answer1: If tips decreased then the overall pay of the wait staff decreased. That would lead to them leaving to find a better paying job.
answer2: Retaining the same generous portions would not affect the wait staffs job. And if their job was not effected, they would not quit.
answer3: If the wage rate were the same and the staff were making the same amount of money then they would not need to look for another job.

context: Editorial: Contrary to popular belief, teaching preschoolers is not especially difficult, for they develop strict systems (e. g. , for sorting toys by shape), which help them to learn, and they are always intensely curious about something new in their world.
question: How does the fact that children intensely curious about new things have very short attention spans weaken the editorial's argument?
answer0: Stating that children have very short attention spans would weaken the argument that teaching preschoolers is not difficult because it would take a lot of time, effort, and energy in order to keep them on task and continually redirect their attention.
answer1: Lower levels of stress typically have a correlation with the ease or difficulty of jobs. Low levels of stress strengthens the argument that teaching preschoolers is not difficult.
answer2: Preschoolers imitating adults would result in the majority of preschoolers acting mature and following routines and directions easily which would strengthen the argument that teaching preschoolers is not difficult.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Trent is a member of the SWAT Team, the most elite tactical unit at the city police department. SWAT apprehends more suspected criminals than all other police units combined. Taken as a whole, the police department solves a higher percentage of crime than ever before in its history. Within the SWAT team, Trent' s four-man unit is the most successful. However, the number of unsolved crime increases every year.
question: Why does the statement that Trent's SWAT team is the city's best police unit not logically resolve the apparent paradox?
answer0: SWAT does not respond to property damage and this is more focused on Trent's SWAT unit and their performance and correlation to increased unsolved crime rate per year.
answer1: If the total number of crimes increases every year, it would make sense that the number of unsolved crimes would also increase no matter how well-performing Trent's unit is.
answer2: If they are the best police unit in the city, one would think they would solve even more crime and so it does not explain the number of unsolved crimes increasing every year
answer3: None of the above choices

context: In a town containing a tourist attraction, hotel and restaurant revenues each increased more rapidly over the past year than did revenue from the sale of passes to the attraction, which are valid for a full year. This led those in charge of the attraction to hypothesize that visitors were illicitly selling or sharing the passes.
question: Why does the fact that during the past year other tourist attractions have opened up in the area help to undermine the hypothesis of those in charge of the tourist attraction?
answer0: This answer does help to undermine the attraction owners' argument. If other attractions have opened up over the past year, it could simply be that the attraction is experiencing more competition. It doesn't have to be true that people are selling or sharing their passes; it could just be that people are choosing to patronize attractions other than this attraction.
answer1: This answer does help to undermine the attraction owners' argument because if this statement is true, then it's probably the higher prices of hotels and meals that have caused the hotel and restaurant industries' profits to increase. If the cost of the attraction passes has NOT increased, it makes sense that they would see less revenue growth than the restaurant/hotel industries.
answer2: This does help to undermine the attraction owners' argument because if the passes are a one-time expense, and then people can visit for a whole year, the repeat visitors are essentially getting in for "Free." They pay the cost upfront, and then the attraction makes no more revenue off them for a whole year. So if people possessing passes are making frequent trips to the attraction throughout the year, it makes sense that the attraction's revenues would stagnate.
answer3: If this was true, it would not undermine the hypothesis of those in charge of the tourist attraction, because it would mean that the increased revenues of the hotel and restaurant industries are NOT due to tourists taking longer vacations (thus paying more for lodging, meals, etc.). Therefore, there must still be some other reason that hotel/restaurant revenues are increasingly more rapidly than the revenue of the tourist attraction, leaving the illegal selling/sharing of passes as a possibility.

main_question.context: In a town containing a tourist attraction, hotel and restaurant revenues each increased more rapidly over the past year than did revenue from the sale of passes to the attraction, which are valid for a full year. This led those in charge of the attraction to hypothesize that visitors were illicitly selling or sharing the passes.

main_question.option: During the past year other tourist attractions have opened up in the area.

context: Many people limit the intake of calories and cholesterol in their diet in order to lose weight and reduce the level of cholesterol in their blood. When a person loses weight, the fat cells in that person' s body decrease in size but not in number. As they decrease in size, fat cells spill the cholesterol they contain into the bloodstream. Ttherefore, a person who goes on a low-calorie, low cholesterol diet __ .
question: What is the reasoning behind the conclusion that someone who begins a high-fat diet might at first have an increased level of cholesterol in his or her blood?
answer0: Increased calorie consumption would not help one lose weight.
answer1: The person on such a diet would lose weight and when losing weight, the fat cells decrease in size.
answer2: The person will initially have their cholesterol dumped into their blood stream contained within their fat cells.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: For a trade embargo against a particular country to succeed, a high degree of both international accord and ability to prevent goods from entering or leaving that country must be sustained. A total blockade of Patria's ports is necessary to an embargo, but such an action would be likely to cause international discord over the embargo.
question: What evidence is there to suggest that the claims do not strongly support the conclusion that the balance of opinion is likely to favor Patria in the event of a blockade?
answer0: Explanation is given that a blockade would only be successful if complete and it is not implied that a simple blockade would give way to a successful embargo.
answer1: Explanation for a successful embargo does not necessarily require a certain international opinion as much as it requires a complete stop of imports and exports.
answer2: There is no indication that Patria is preferred or not.
answer3: The mention of how thorough an embargo would have to be to be successful supports the idea that an embargo would be likely to fail.

context: DataCom, a company that filed many patents last year, was financially more successful last year than were its competitors, none of which filed many patents. It is ttherefore likely that DataCom owed its greater financial success to the fact that it filed many patents last year.
question: Why is the argument not considered to be flawed for applying a generalization to an exceptional case?
answer0: The author assumes that patent filings is the only reason why DataCom performed better than its competitors, without providing for the possibility of other factors or explaining why patents are the main factor.
answer1: There is no evidence provided in the article that DataCom's outperformance is an exceptional or out of the ordinary case of patent filings driving financial success.
answer2: The article does not provide specifics of how DataCom's patents drove financial out performance versus its competitors or consider that other relevant factors like marketing or operating efficiency could be giving DataCom a competitive advantage.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: An analysis of the XO Candy Corporation divided its products into two categories: chocolate-based candies and non-chocolate-based candies. The analysis shows that, unlike the non-chocolate candies, few chocolate candies sold enough units to be profitable. Nevertheless, stopping production of the unprofitable chocolate candies will not necessarily make the entire company more profitable, because__ .
question: What is the logical basis for concluding that a large proportion of XO's customers are those who initially bought XO's chocolate candies and eventually went on to buy other candies made by XO?
answer0: No part of the argument suggests that the date that certain product categories were developed is of relevance to the sensibility of what categories to continue producing.
answer1: Customers being attracted to a certain overall unprofitable product category before moving on to be more regular and loyal consumers of the more profitable product category explains why as the statement says, the former category is worthwhile to keep around for overall company profitability.
answer2: If a product category is not especially profitable, merely changing the particular products in that category doesn't mean that the category will necessarily become profitable.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: A new gardening rake with an S-shaped handle reduces compression stress on the spine during the pull stroke to about one-fifth of what it is with a straight-handled rake. During the push stroke, however, compression stress is five times more with the new rake than with a straight-handled rake. Neither the push stroke nor the pull stroke with a straight-handled rake produces enough compression stress to cause injury, but compression stress during the push stroke with the new rake is above the danger level. Ttherefore, straight-handled rakes are better than the new rakes for minimizing risk of spinal injury.
question: Why is it valid to conclude that the conclusion is properly drawn from the premises given if it is true that compression stress resulting from pushing is the only cause of injuries to the spine that occur as a result of raking?
answer0: If compression stress resulting from pushing is the only cause of spine injuries from raking, then a straight-handled rake is better than an s-handled rake because a straight-handled rake puts less pressure stress on the spine during the push stroke.
answer1: The comparison is only between s-handled and straight-handled rakes, so other handle designs or the possibility of other designs is not relevant to the argument.
answer2: It would not be necessary for all strokes to be push strokes, only that the s-handle creates more pressure on the spine with any push stroke.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Most people are indignant at the suggestion that they are not reliable authorities about their real wants. Such self-knowledge, however, is not the easiest kind of knowledge to acquire. Indeed, acquiring it often requires hard and even potentially risky work. To avoid such effort, people unconsciously convince themselves that they want what society says they should want.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the argument's main point is that knowledge of what one really wants is as desirable as it is usually thought to be?
answer0: The argument does not make any claims about what people should want, only that people unconsciously align their wants with what society believes they should want.
answer1: The argument claims that knowledge of what one really wants is difficult to achieve, but it does not make any judgment on how desirable this knowledge is.
answer2: The argument discusses people's avoidance of putting in effort to understand their real wants, but not avoidance of making difficult decisions.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: In the last election, 89 percent of reporters voted for the incumbent. The content of news programs reveals that reporters allowed the personal biases reflected in this voting pattern to affect their news coverage: 54 percent of coverage concerning the challenger was negative, compared with only 30 percent of that concerning the incumbent.
question: Why is the argument not logically flawed for disregarding the possibility that reporters generally fear losing access to incumbents more than they fear losing access to challengers?
answer0: The electorate's voting behavior does not affect the arguments logic.
answer1: There could be actual news that supports the reporters views regardless of their biases.
answer2: It actually supports the probability that they fear losing access to incumbents more.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Chinh: Television producers should not pay attention to the preferences of the viewing public when making creative decisions. Great painters do not consider what the museum-going public wants to see. Lana: But television is expressly for the viewing public. So a producer is more like a CEO than like an artist. Just as a company would be foolhardy not to consider consumers' tastes when developing products, the TV producer must consider viewers' preferences.
question: What is Lana's reasoning for claiming that Chinh's argument is flawed because it offers a faulty analogy?
answer0: While Chinh's argument does indeed fail to consider this possibility, this shortcoming is not cited by Lana.
answer1: Chinh's argument does not rely upon a sample of consumers.
answer2: Chinh's argument is not circular in nature but rather is based upon an analogy.
answer3: Lana argues that Chinh's analogy comparing painters to television producers is faulty, and a producer is more like a CEO than an artist.

context: Footwear designer John de los Santos last year released several limited editions of his best-known model of sneaker in exotic colors and prints. Although the new releases were priced substantially higher than their counterparts in more traditional colors, they sold out within a week of their release, and have since been selling on the resale market for up to four times the original price. The cost of producing the sneakers in exotic prints is no greater than that of producing them in more traditional colors, so de los Santos could earn a higher profit per unit by producing a greater percentage of his sneakers in such prints.
question: What is the reasoning behind the assumption that consumers' willingness to pay higher prices for the exotic sneakers was not influenced by the relative scarcity of those sneakers in drawing the conclusion?
answer0: The passage does not go into any detail concerning counterfeit products and how easy or difficult it would be to reproduce the sneakers. As no mention of counterfeit products were made it would be difficult to make an assumption regarding the ability to do so.
answer1: The passage focuses only on De los Santo’s designs and not about the competition of other designers and no mention is made as to the price differences between Santo and his competitors.
answer2: The passage states that consumers will continue to pay higher prices for the exotic colored shoes even if more are produced which reasons that consumers are not paying higher prices for the product because of scarcity or limited production.
answer3: No information is given concerning Santos competitors and what they have produced in the past or will be producing in the near future.

context: The primary task of a university is to educate. But to teach well, professors must be informed about new developments in their disciplines, and that requires research. Yet many universities cannot afford to support faculty research adequately. So a lack of funds for research adversely affects the degree to which a university can fulfill its central mission.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that, in order to be able to teach well, university professors must conduct research based on the argument?
answer0: The text states that lack of research by the educators will have a varying degree of adverse effects. Since that will effect some of the ability to teach effectively, the quality of education is reduced.
answer1: The text states that the primary task is to educate. It does not state it has to be effective. It implies that is should be effective, but does not state that it has to.
answer2: The text states that research is needed to stay informed about developments in their field. That research does not have to be their own research and they can still teach well if they use outside research in their field.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.question: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the conclusion of the argument?
main_question.option: In order to be able to teach well, university professors must conduct research.

context: The corpus callosum -- the thick band of nerve fibers connecting the brain' s two hemispheres -- of a musician is on average larger than that of a nonmusician. The differences in the size of corpora callosa are particularly striking when adult musicians who began training around the age of seven are compared to adult nonmusicians. Ttherefore, musical training, particularly when it begins at a young age, causes certain anatomic brain changes.
question: Why does the argument not depend on the assumption that musical training late in life does not cause anatomic changes to the brain?
answer0: This may or may not be true, but the argument rests on comparing their corpora callosa to nonmusicians, not to each other.
answer1: We don't know if there are other activities which grow the corpus callosum, so there may be adult nonmusicians with a larger corpus callosum, but we don't know either way.
answer2: The changes are just not as striking, which mean they still occur.
answer3: If musical training grows the corpora callosa, it is necessarily true that a beginner with no training will be average.

context: Child-rearing Expert: Parents should never discipline their children in public. Some children who are disciplined in public suffer from attention deficit disorder. answer2: The expert explicitly states that assistance is the preferred method of handling children with the disorder.

context: Political scientist: Some analysts point to the government' s acceptance of the recent protest rally as proof that the government supports freedom of popular expression. The message of the protest rally was one that the government entirely supports.

context: The top prize in architecture, the Pritzker Prize, is awarded for individual achievement, like Nobel Prizes for science. But architects are judged by their buildings, and buildings are the result of teamwork. As achievements, buildings are not like scientific discoveries, but like movies, which compete for awards for best picture. Thus, it would be better if the top prize in architecture were awarded to the best building rather than the best architect.
question: Why does the argument not succeed in concluding that one type of object has more inherent value than the other by making a distinction between two different types of objects?
answer0: The argument does not make any value judgments about the different types of objects or achievements discussed.
answer1: The argument concludes that awards in architecture should be given for buildings rather than individuals due to the achievements being the result of teamwork, comparing to how awards are given for movies, which are another type of achievement done through teamwork.
answer2: The argument does compare between awards for architecture and awards for movies and scientific discoveries, but it does not make any claim about the applicability of criticisms from one type of award to any others.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: The Minoan civilization flourished on the island of Crete around 2000 B. (C) The discovery on Crete of large numbers of bronze implements and the furnaces used in their manufacture shows that the Minoans had a thriving bronze industry. Moreover, many bronze artifacts from this period that are similar in style to those produced on Crete have been found in southern Greece. Hence it is probable that, besides making bronzeware for domestic use, the Minoans exported bronzeware to southern Greece.
question: Explain why the fact that copper and tin, the main ingredients of bronze, were present in Southern Greece does not strengthen the argument given.
answer0: It would be possible for the Minoans to export pottery and not export their bronze items.
answer1: The presence of the bronze artifacts in southern Greece, without any furnaces or other means that could be used to produce them, makes it more likely that they were indeed imported from Crete.
answer2: Even if they had access to copper and tin in Southern Greece, if they had no way to forge them into bronze, then they had to have gotten the bronze artifacts from another civilization.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Journalists agree universally that lying is absolutely taboo. Yet, while many reporters claim that spoken words ought to be quoted verbatim, many others believe that tightening a quote from a person who is interviewed is legitimate on grounds that the speaker' s remarks would have been more concise if the speaker had written them instead. Also, many reporters believe that, to expose wrongdoing, failing to identify oneself as a reporter is permissible, while others condemn such behavior as a type of lying.
question: Explain why the information does not support the claim that omission of the truth is the same thing as lying.

context: Trustee: The recent exhibit at the art museum was extensively covered by the local media, and this coverage seems to have contributed to the record-breaking attendance it drew. If the attendance at the exhibit had been low, the museum would have gone bankrupt and closed permanently, so the museum could not have remained open had it not been for the coverage from the local media.
question: Why is the reasoning in the trustee's argument not considered to be flawed for assuming that most people who read articles about the exhibit also attended the exhibit?
answer0: It does not matter what another exhibit has done in the past.
answer1: The media covered it does not necessarily have an impact in all situations so the conclusion could not have been presupposed.
answer2: This is perfect causation without correlation. There is no way to know whether there would have been many attendees, there is no control group.

context: The following exchange occurred after the Baseball Coach' s team suffered a heartbreaking loss in the final inning. Reporter: The team clearly did not rise to the challenge. Baseball Coach: Hitting with runners in scoring position was not the reason we lost this game. We made numerous errors in the field, and our pitchers gave out too many free passes. context: In recent years, many cabinetmakers have been winning acclaim as artists. But since furniture must be useful, cabinetmakers must exercise their craft with an eye to the practical utility of their product. For this reason, cabinetmaking is not art.
question: Why does the fact that some furniture is made to be placed in museums, where it will not be used by anyone, not support drawing the conclusion from the reason given for that conclusion?
answer0: Furniture must be useful and practical. For this reason the passage tells us that cabinetworking is not art.
answer1: Making a generalization about what groups of people should or should not be concerned with is difficult and dangerous and is up to each individual. The passage does not make these inferences or generalizations and is focused solely upon stating that furniture is not art.
answer2: The passage does not go into this subject and is focused on whether or not furniture can be considered art and not how concerned artists are about the value of the products they create.
answer3: Placing furniture in a museum not to be used but to be viewed would make it art, which contradicts the passage’s conclusion that furniture is not art.

context: In a study of the relationship between aggression and television viewing in nursery school children, many interesting interactions among family styles, aggression, and television viewing were found. High aggression occurred in both high-viewing and low-viewing children and this seemed to be related to parental lifestyle. High-achieving, competitive, middle-class parents, whose children did not watch much television, had more aggressive children than parents who planned their lives in an organized, child-centered way, which included larger amounts of television viewing.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that low levels of television viewing often lead to high levels of aggression among children based on the passage?
answer0: The passage lists at least two different factors other than TV viewing which might influence the observed aggression levels, suggesting that no factor alone is responsible.
answer1: The passage indicates a correlation between aggression and parenting style but does not establish sole causation, as alternative factors such as inherited traits or TV viewing are also mentioned.
answer2: The passage does not establish the relative importance of any of the factors compared to the others which might also be contributing to differing levels of aggression.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Chemical fertilizers not only create potential health hazards, they also destroy earthworms, which are highly beneficial to soil. answer1: This statement is merely a side note about the benefits of earthworms and does not state anything about fertilizers.

context: Business ethicist: Managers of corporations have an obligation to serve shareholders as the shareholders would want to be served. Ttherefore, corporate managers have an obligation to act in the shareholders' best interest.

answer0: Assuming all shareholders want to be served in identical ways does not mean that it would be in the best interest of all shareholders.
answer1: The obligation to serve shareholders as they would want to be served and therefore being obligated to serve them in their best interest assumes that shareholders want to be served in their own best interest.

context: The chances that tropical storms will develop in a given area increase whenever the temperature of a large body of water in that area exceeds 26 degrees Celsius to a depth of about 60 meters. If the amount of carbon dioxide in the Earth' s atmosphere continues to increase, the temperatures of all of the Earth' s waters will rise, with the result that the number of large bodies of water whose temperatures exceed 26 degrees Celsius to a depth of about 60 meters will eventually be greater than it is today.
question: What is the basis for concluding that the statements above strongly support the conclusion that there are likely to be more tropical storms if the amount of carbon dioxide in the Earth's atmosphere continues to increase?
answer0: Increased carbon leads to increased temperatures which leads to more storm activity, so this is necessarily true.
answer1: The opposite is stated, that increased carbon leads to increased temperatures which leads to stronger storms.
answer2: This cause and effect should be reversed, since increased carbon leads to increased temperatures.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Kernland imposes a high tariff on the export of unprocessed cashew nuts in order to ensure that the nuts are sold to domestic processing plants. If the tariff were lifted and unprocessed cashews were sold at world market prices, more farmers could profit by growing cashews. However, since all the processing plants are in urban areas, removing the tariff would seriously hamper the government' s effort to reduce urban unemployment over the next five years.
question: How does the fact that a lack of profitable crops is driving an increasing number of small farmers in Kernland off their land and into the cities weaken the argument?
answer0: Regardless what price processors pay for the unprocessed cashews, they will sell them abroad at higher world market prices if allowed to do so.
answer1: If true then removing the tariff could actually improve employment, particularly in rural farming areas, create more raw products which in turn could reduce unemployment in urban areas as well.
answer2: Other cashew producing countries subsidizing their processing plants is irrelevant because the farmers would still sell the unprocessed cashews abroad at world prices.
answer3: What by-products are made from cashews does not affect the outcome of the tariff decision.

context: More pedestrian injuries occur at crosswalks marked by both striping on the roadway and flashing lights than occur at crosswalks not so marked. Obviously these so-called safety features are a waste of taxpayer money.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument not considered to be flawed for assuming that crosswalks with both striping and flashing lights have no other safety features?
answer0: The passage did not state anything about using less expensive features.
answer1: Nothing is being taken granted in the passage regarding failure to reduce the number of injuries.
answer2: The passage is discussing it being a waste of taxpayer money, not that it has no other safety features.

context: Historian: During the Industrial Revolution, for the first time in history, the productivity of the economy grew at a faster rate than the population and thus dramatically improved living standards. An economist theorizes that this growth was made possible by the spread of values such as hard work and thrift. But successful explanations need to be based on facts, so no one should accept this explanation until historical evidence demonstrates that a change in values occurred prior to the Industrial Revolution.

answer0: It may have grown at a faster rate but the question is why did it.

answer3: None of the above choices

context: Certain bacteria that produce hydrogen sulfide as a waste product would die if directly exposed to oxygen. The hydrogen sulfide reacts with oxygen, removing it and so preventing it from harming the bacteria. Furthermore, the hydrogen sulfide tends to kill other organisms in the area, thereby providing the bacteria with a source of food. As a result, a dense colony of these bacteria produces for itself an environment in which it can continue to thrive indefinitely.
question: What evidence is there to suggest that the hydrogen sulfide produced by the bacteria does not strongly support the claim that it kills other organisms in the area by reacting with and removing oxygen?
answer0: The passage does not specify the fraction of the organisms killed by the hydrogen sulfide that can be food for the bacteria, it could be all of them or less than half of them.
answer1: The passage does not mention that the hydrogen sulfide kills other organisms indirectly like that, instead it implies that the hydrogen sulfide kills them directly.
answer2: Yes the passage clearly says that it takes a high density of the bacteria to create an environment in which it can survive indefinitely.
answer3: None of the above choices

Furthermore, the hydrogen sulfide tends to kill other organisms in the area, thereby providing the bacteria with a source of food. As a result, a dense colony of these bacteria produces for itself an environment in which it can continue to thrive indefinitely.
main_question.question: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the information above?
main_question.option: The hydrogen sulfide produced by the bacteria kills other organisms in the area by reacting with and removing oxygen.

context: Consumers planning to buy recreational equipment tend to buy higher quality, more expensive equipment when the economy is strong than when it is weak. Hill and Dale is a business that sells high-quality, expensive camping and hiking equipment in Boravia. Although all the signs are that Boravia' s economy is now entering a period of sustained strength, the managers of the business do not expect a substantial increase in sales.
question: What is the basis for why the fact that the economic upturn is likely to allow Boravia's national parks, where most of the camping and hiking is done, to receive extra funding to improve their visitor facilities does not provide the strongest justification for the managers' judgment?
answer0: Improvements to hiking and camping equipment would have a positive impact on sales, as these products would become more attractive to people.
answer1: Improvements to Boravia's national parks would have a positive impact on sales, as more people would be motivated to go to the national parks and use camping and hiking equipment there.
answer2: High interest in spending time in wilderness areas means that a lot of people need hiking and camping equipment in order to be prepared when spending time in wilderness areas, which would mean relatively high sales for Hill and Dale.
answer3: Since Boravia's economy is entering a period of strength, people will be more likely to vacation overseas instead of going camping, which reduces the demand for camping and hiking equipment and therefore makes a substantial increase in sales of such equipment unlikely.

context: In response to high mortality in area hospitals, surgery was restricted to emergency procedures during a five-week period. Mortality in these hospitals was found to have fallen by nearly one-third during the period. The number of deaths rose again when elective surgery (surgery that can be postponed) was resumed. It can be concluded that, before the five-week period, the risks of elective surgery had been incurred unnecessarily often in the area.
question: Explain why the fact that the physicians planning elective surgery performed before the five-week period had fully informed the patients who would undergo it of the possible risks of the procedures does not seriously undermine the conclusion.
answer0: A patient dying of an infection after surgery strengthens the argument that the surgery is too risky.
answer1: Even if the physicians informed the patients of the risks the risks might still have been unnecessary.
answer2: Even if elective surgery is less risky than emergency surgery in general the risks for the elective surgeries in this case could have been unnecessary.
answer3: None of the above choices

answer1: Even if elective surgery is less risky than emergency surgery in general the risks for the elective surgeries in this case could have been unnecessary.
answer2: A patient dying of an infection after surgery strengthens the argument that the surgery is too risky.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.context: In response to high mortality in area hospitals, surgery was restricted to emergency procedures during a five-week period. Mortality in these hospitals was found to have fallen by nearly one-third during the period. The number of deaths rose again when elective surgery (surgery that can be postponed) was resumed. It can be concluded that, before the five-week period, the risks of elective surgery had been incurred unnecessarily often in the area.
main_question.question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously undermines the conclusion above?
main_question.option: Even if a surgical procedure is successful, the patient can die of a hospital-contracted infection with a bacterium that is resistant to antibiotic treatment.

context: Professor Riley characterized the university president' s speech as inflammatory and argued that it was ttherefore inappropriate. However, Riley has had a long-standing feud with the president, and so we should not conclude that her speech was inflammatory solely on the basis of Riley' s testimony. Ttherefore, unless there are independent reasons to deem the president' s speech inflammatory, it is not true that her speech was inappropriate.
question: Why is the argument not considered to be invalid due to its failure to sufficiently consider the possibility that Riley's animosity toward the university president is well founded?
answer0: The author shows that Riley may be biased against the president but they do not state the Riley has anything in particular to gain in this situation.
answer1: The author argues that Riley's animosity toward the university may cause bias and this would be the case whether the animosity was well founded or not.
answer2: The author argues that unless the speech can be proven to be inflammatory it can not be inappropriate but the speech could not be inflammatory yet still be inappropriate in some other way.
answer3: The author argues for the stance that the speech was likely appropriate, therefore the speech being appropriate for some audiences is in line with their argument.

context: The traditional view of the Roman emperor Caligula as a cruel and insane tyrant has been challenged by some modern historians. They point out that little documentation of Caligula' s alleged cruelty or outrageous behavior survives from the time of his reign and that the histories that have come down to us were written by his enemies.
question: Why does the fact that people who have lived under someone regarded as a cruel tyrant are more likely to view that person unfavorably than favorably not add support for the challenge from the modem historians?
answer0: The passage does not mention if modern tyrants are more cruel or not.
answer1: This just shows that rulers of this time had a certain standard and Caligula was no more cruel than anyone else.
answer2: The passage mentions that the bad things written about Caligula were by his enemies, it never mentions people that he was cruel to.
answer3: The passage does not mention that there was a scarcity of documents.

context: The children in the second grade at a local elementary school scored lower on tests of math skills this year than the second graders did last year. The school board blames the disappointing results on the budget cuts that forced the school to consolidate several classes of second-grade students, thus depriving them of the individualized attention that they had previously enjoyed.
question: How does the fact that the test that the second graders took this year was not more difficult than the test that the second graders took last year support the explanation offered by the school board for the students' lower test scores?
answer0: This undermines the board's argument by suggesting a possible alternative explanation for the decline in test performance.
answer1: This is not relevant to the argument as we are not told whether or not these other schools experienced a decline in test performance.
answer2: If true, this would exclude the only other possible explanation which is mentioned in the passage to the one suggested by the board for the difference in test performance.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Migraines are caused by changes in certain blood vessels of the brain that result in a local disturbance in the action of a specific nerve-activating chemical. answer0: Drug L disrupts the action of other chemicals in the brain while Drug K does not. No other effects are listed as being associated with Drug L other than the cessation of migraines.
answer1: Each drug is stated to be effective in restoring the effects of the chemical imbalance that is resulting in the person experiencing the migraine.
answer2: The two drugs are stated to have the exact same restorative effects and neither is listed as being either faster or slower than the other.
answer3: Differences in administration times are not mentioned in the passage and neither is effectiveness based upon the timing of when each drug is administered following onset of a migraine.

context: Appendicitis (inflammation of the appendix) is potentially fatal; consequently, patients with symptoms strongly suggesting appendicitis almost always have their appendix removed. The appropriate surgery is low-risk but performed unnecessarily in about 20 percent of all cases. A newly developed internal scan for appendicitis is highly accurate, producing two misdiagnoses for every 98 correct diagnoses. Clearly, using this test, doctors can largely avoid unnecessary removals of the appendix without, however, performing any fewer necessary ones than before, since __.
question: Why does the fact that all of the patients who are diagnosed with this test as having appendicitis do, in fact, have appendicitis not logically complete the passage?
answer0: If there are two misdiagnoses for very 98 correct diagnoses, then not all of the patients diagnosed with this test do in fact have appendicitis.
answer1: If misdiagnoses produced by this test are always instances of attributing appendicitis to someone who does not have it, then there are a few unnecessary surgeries performed but no necessary surgeries that are not performed.
answer2: Whether or not a patient has more than one of the symptoms associated with appendicitis does not tell us anything about the accuracy of the test, or the proportion of necessary to unnecessary surgeries, or whether all necessary surgeries are performed.
answer3: Symptoms in the patients who are misdiagnosed does not tell us anything about the accuracy of the test, how many unnecessary surgeries are avoided, or whether all the necessary surgeries are in fact performed.
